column10673: For, from this promise he concluded, that it followed in reason, "He must be willing."
column10674: The text also gives some ground for us to draw the same conclusion.
column10675: "And him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out."
column10676: Here is his willingness asserted, as well as his power suggested.
column10677: It is worth your observation, that Abraham's faith considered rather God's power than his willingness; that is, he drew his conclusion, "I shall have a child," from the power that was in God to fulfil the promise to him.
column10678: For he concluded he was willing to give him one, else he would not have promised one.
column10679: "He staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was strong in faith, giving glory to God; and being fully persuaded that what he had promised he was able also to perform" (Rev 4:20,21).
column10680: But was not his faith exercised, or tried, about his willingness too?
column10681: No, there was no show of reason for that, because he had promised it.
column10682: Indeed, had he not promised it, he might lawfully have doubted it; but since he had promised it, there was left no ground at all for doubting, because his willingness to give a son was demonstrated in his promising him a son.
column10683: These words, therefore, are sufficient ground to encourage any coming sinner that Christ is willing to his power to receive him; and since he hath power also to do what he will, there is no ground at all left to the coming sinner any more to doubt; but to come in full hope of acceptance, and of being received unto grace and mercy.
column10685: He saith not, and him that is come; but, and him that cometh; that is, and him whose heart begins to move after me, who is leaving all for my sake; him who is looking out, who is on his journey to me.
column10686: We must, therefore, distinguish betwixt coming, and being come to Jesus Christ.
column10687: He that is come to him has attained of him more sensibly what he felt before that he wanted, than he has that but yet is coming to him.
column10688: [Advantages to the man that is come to Christ.]
column10689: A man that is come to Christ hath the advantage of him that is but coming to him; and that in seven things.
column10691: He that is come to Christ is nearer to him than he that is but coming to him; for he that is but coming to him is yet, in some sense, at a distance from him; as it is said of the coming prodigal, "And while he was yet a great way off" (Luke 15:20).
column10692: Now he that is nearer to him hath the best sight of him; and so is able to make the best judgment of his wonderful grace and beauty, as God saith, "Let them come near, then let them speak" (Isa 41:1).
column10693: And as the apostle John saith, "And we have seen and do testify that the Father sent the Son to be the Saviour of the world" (1 John 4:14).
column10694: He that is not yet come, though he is coming, is not fit, not being indeed capable to make that judgment of the worth and glory of the grace of Christ, as he is that is come to him, and hath seen and beheld it.
column10695: Therefore, sinner, suspend thy judgment till thou art come nearer.
column10697: He that is come to Christ has the advantage of him that is but coming, in that he is eased of his burden; for he that is but coming is not eased of his burden (Matt 11:28).
column10698: He that is come has cast his burden upon the Lord.
column10699: By faith he hath seen himself released thereof; but he that is but coming hath it yet, as to sense and feeling, upon his own shoulders.
column10700: "Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden," implies, that their burden, though they are coming, is yet upon them, and so will be till indeed they are come to him.
column10702: He that is come to Christ has the advantage of him that is but coming in this also, namely, he hath drank of the sweet and soul refreshing water of life; but he that is but coming hath not.
column10703: "If any man thirst, let him come unto me and drink" (John 7:37).
column10704: Mark, He must come to him before he drinks: according to that of the prophet, "Ho!
column10705: every one that thirsteth, come ye to the waters."
column10706: He drinketh not as he cometh, but when he is come to the waters (Isa 55:1).
column10708: He that is come to Christ hath the advantage of him that as yet is but coming in this also, to wit, he is not so terrified with the noise, and, as I may call it, hue and cry, which the avenger of blood makes at the heels of him that yet is but coming to him.
column10709: When the slayer was on his flight to the city of his refuge, he had the noise or fear of the avenger of blood at his heels; but when he was come to the city, and was entered thereinto, that noise ceased.
column10710: Even so it is with him that is but coming to Jesus Christ, he heareth many a dreadful sound in is ear; sounds of death and damnation, which he that is come is at present freed from.
column10711: Therefore he saith, "Come, and I will give you rest."
column10712: And so he saith again, "We that have believed, do enter into rest," as he said, &c. (Heb 4).
column10714: He, therefore, that is come to Christ, is not so subject to those dejections, and castings down, by reason of the rage and assaults of the evil one, as is the man that is but coming to Jesus Christ, though he has temptations too.
column10715: "And as he was yet a-coming, the devil threw him down, and tare him" (Luke 9:42).
column10716: For he has, though Satan still roareth upon him, those experimental comforts and refreshments, to wit, in his treasury, to present himself with, in times of temptation and conflict; which he that is but coming has not.
column10718: He that is come to Christ has the advantage of him that is but coming to him, in this also, to wit, he hath upon him the wedding garment, &c., but he that is coming has not.
column10719: The prodigal, when coming home to his father, was clothed with nothing but rags, and was tormented with an empty belly; but when he was come, the best robe is brought out, also the gold ring, and the shoes, yea, they are put upon him, to his great rejoicing.
column10720: The fatted calf was killed for him; the music was struck up to make him merry; and thus also the Father himself sang of him, "This my son was dead, and is alive again; was lost and is found" (Luke 15:18,19).
column10722: In a word, he that is come to Christ, his groans and tears, his doubts and fears, are turned into songs and praises; for that he hath now received the atonement, and the earnest of his inheritance; but he that is but yet a-coming, hath not those praises nor songs of deliverance with him; nor has he as yet received the atonement and earnest of his inheritance, which is, the sealing testimony of the Holy Ghost, through the sprinkling of the blood of Christ upon his conscience, for he is not come (Rom 5:11; Eph 1:13; Heb 12:22-24).
column10725: There is further to be gathered from this word cometh, these following particulars:-- 1.
column10726: That Jesus Christ hath his eye upon, and takes notice of, the first moving of the heart of a sinner after himself.
column10727: Coming sinner, thou canst not move with desires after Christ, but he sees the working of those desires in thy heart.
column10728: "All my desire," said David, "is before thee; and my groaning is not hid from thee" (Psa 38:9).
column10729: This he spake, as he was coming, after he had backslidden, to the Lord Jesus Christ.
column10730: It is said of the prodigal, that while he was yet a great way off, his father saw him, had his eye upon him, and upon the going out of his heart after him (Luke 15:20).
column10731: When Nathanael was come to Jesus Christ, the Lord said to them that stood before him, "Behold an Israelite indeed, in whom is no guile."
column10732: But Nathanael answered him, "Whence knowest thou me?"
column10733: Jesus answered, "Before that Philip called thee, when thou wast under the fig-tree, I saw thee."
column10734: There, I suppose, Nathanael was pouring out of his soul to God for mercy, or that he would give him good understanding about the Messias to come; and Jesus saw all the workings of his honest heart at that time (John 1:47,48).
column10735: Zaccheus also had some secret movings of heart, such as they were, towards Jesus Christ, when he ran before, and climbed up the tree to see him; and the Lord Jesus Christ had his eye upon him: therefore, when he was come to the place, he looked up to him, bids him come down, "For today," said he, "I must abide at thy house;" to wit, in order to the further completing the work of grace in his soul (Luke 19:1-9).
column10738: As Jesus Christ hath his eye upon, so he hath his heart open to receive, the coming sinner.
column10739: This is verified by the text: "And him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out."
column10740: This is also discovered by his preparing of the way, in his making of it easy (as may be) to the coming sinner; which preparation is manifest by those blessed words, "I will in no wise cast out;" of which more when we come to the place.
column10741: And while "he was yet a great way off, his Father saw him, and had compassion, and ran, and fell on his neck, and kissed him" (Luke 15:20).
column10742: All these expressions do strongly prove that the heart of Christ is open to receive the coming sinner.
column10744: As Jesus Christ has his eye upon, and his heart open to receive, so he hath resolved already that nothing shall alienate his heart from receiving the coming sinner.
column10745: No sins of the coming sinner, nor the length of the time that he hath abode in them, shall by any means prevail with Jesus Christ to reject him.
column10746: Coming sinner, thou art coming to a loving Lord Jesus!
column10748: These words therefore are dropped from his blessed mouth, on purpose that the coming sinner might take encouragement to continue on his journey, until he be come indeed to Jesus Christ.
column10749: It was doubtless a great encouragement to blind Bartimeus, that Jesus Christ stood still and called him, when he was crying, "Jesus, thou Son of David, have mercy on me;" therefore, it is said, he cast away his garment, "rose, and came to Jesus" (Mark 10:46).
column10750: Now, if a call to come hath such encouragement in it, what is a promise of receiving such, but an encouragement much more?
column10751: And observe it, though he had a call to come, yet not having a promise, his faith was forced to work upon a mere consequence, saying, He calls me; and surely since he calls me, he will grant me my desire.
column10753: but coming sinner, thou hast no need to go so far about as to draw (in this matter) consequences, because thou hast plain promises: "And him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out."
column10754: Here is full, plain, yea, what encouragement one can desire; for, suppose thou wast admitted to make a promise thyself, and Christ should attest that he would fulfil it upon the sinner that cometh to him, Couldst thou make a better promise?
column10755: Couldst thou invent a more full, free, or larger promise?
column10756: a promise that looks at the first moving of the heart after Jesus Christ?
column10757: a promise that declares, yea, that engageth Christ Jesus to open his heart to receive the coming sinner?
column10758: yea, further, a promise that demonstrateth that the Lord Jesus is resolved freely to receive, and will in no wise cast out, nor means to reject, the soul of the coming sinner!
column10759: For all this lieth fully in this promise, and doth naturally flow therefrom.
column10760: Here thou needest not make use of far-fetched consequences, nor strain thy wits, to force encouraging arguments from the text.
column10761: Coming sinner, the words are plain: "And him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out."
column10762: [TWO SORTS OF SINNERS COMING TO CHRIST.]
column10764: There are two sorts of sinners that are coming to Jesus Christ.
column10765: First, Him that hath never, while of late, 14 at all began to come.
column10766: Second, Him that came formerly, and after that went back; but hath since bethought himself, and is now coming again.
column10767: Both these sorts of sinners are intended by the HIM in the text, as is evident; because both are now the coming sinners.
column10771: --For the first of these: the sinner that hath never, while of late, began to come, his way is more easy; I do not say, more plain and open to come to Christ than is the other--those last not having the clog of a guilty conscience, for the sin of backsliding, hanging at their heels.
column10772: But all the encouragement of the gospel, with what invitations are therein contained to coming sinners, are as free and as open to the one as to the other; so that they may with the same freedom and liberty, as from the Word, both alike claim interest in the promise.
column10773: "All things are ready;" all things for the coming backsliders, as well as for the others: "Come to the wedding."
column10774: "And let him that is athirst come" (Matt 22:1-4; Rev 22:17).
column10777: --But having spoke to the first of these already, I shall here pass it by; and shall speak a word or two to him that is coming, after backsliding, to Jesus Christ for life.
column10778: Thy way, O thou sinner of a double dye, thy way is open to come to Jesus Christ.
column10779: I mean thee, whose heart, after long backsliding, doth think of turning to him again.
column10780: Thy way, I say, is open to him, as is the way of the other sorts of comers; as appears by what follows:-- 1.
column10781: Because the text makes no exception against thee.
column10782: It doth not say, And any him but a backslider, any him but him.
column10783: The text doth not thus object, but indefinitely openeth wide its golden arms to every coming soul, without the least exception; therefore thou mayest come.
column10784: And take heed that thou shut not that door against thy soul by unbelief, which God has opened by his grace.
column10786: Nay, the text is so far from excepting against thy coming, that it strongly suggesteth that thou art one of the souls intended, O thou coming backslider; else what need that clause have been so inserted, "I will in no wise cast out?"
column10787: As who should say, Though those that come now are such as have formerly backslidden, I will in "no wise" cast away the fornicator, the covetous, the railer, the drunkard, or other common sinners, nor yet the backslider neither.
column10789: That the backslider is intended is evident, (1.)
column10790: For that he is sent to by name, "Go, tell his disciples and Peter" (Mark 16:7).
column10791: But Peter was a godly man.
column10792: True, but he was also a backslider, yea, a desperate backslider: he had denied his Master once, twice, thrice, cursing and swearing that he knew him not.
column10793: If this was not backsliding, if this was not an high and eminent backsliding, yea, a higher backsliding than thou art capable of, I have thought amiss.
column10794: Again, when David had backslidden, and had committed adultery and murder in his backsliding, he must be sent to by name: "And," saith the text, "the Lord sent Nathan unto David."
column10795: And he sent him to tell him, after he had brought him to unfeigned acknowledgment, "The Lord hath also put away, or forgiven thy sin" (2 Sam 12:1,13).
column10796: This man also was far gone: he took a man's wife, and killed her husband, and endeavoured to cover all with wicked dissimulation.
column10797: He did this, I say, after God had exalted him, and showed him great favour; wherefore his transgression was greatened also by the prophet with mighty aggravations; yet he was accepted, and that with gladness, at the first step he took in his returning to Christ.
column10798: For the first step of the backslider's return is to say, sensibly and unfeignedly, "I have sinned;" but he had no sooner said thus, but a pardon was produced, yea, thrust into his bosom: "And Nathan said unto David, The Lord hath also put away thy sin."
column10800: As the person of the backslider is mentioned by name, so also is his sin, that, if possible, thy objections against thy returning to Christ may be taken out of thy way; I say, thy sin also is mentioned by name, and mixed, as mentioned, with words of grace and favour: "I will heal their backsliding, I will love them freely" (Hosea 14:4).
column10803: Nay, further, thou art not only mentioned by name, and thy sin by the nature of it, but thou thyself, who art a returning backslider, put, (a) Amongst God's Israel, "Return, thou backsliding Israel, saith the Lord; and I will not cause mine anger to fall upon you; for I am merciful, saith the Lord, and I will not keep anger for ever" (Jer 3:12).
column10804: (b) Thou art put among his children; among his children to whom he is married.
column10805: "Turn, O backsliding children, for I am married unto you" (verse 14).
column10806: (c) Yea, after all this, as if his heart was so full of grace for them, that he was pressed until he had uttered it before them, he adds, "Return, ye backsliding children, and I will heal your backslidings" (verse 22).
column10808: Nay, further, the Lord hath considered, that the shame of thy sin hath stopped thy mouth, and made thee almost a prayerless man; and therefore he saith unto thee, "Take with you words, and turn to the Lord: say unto him, Take away all iniquity, and receive us graciously."
column10809: See his grace, that himself should put words of encouragement into the heart of a backslider; as he saith in another place, "I taught Ephraim to go, taking him by the arms."
column10810: This is teaching him to go indeed, to hold him up by the arms; by the chin, as we say (Hosea 14:2; 11:3).
column10811: From what has been said, I conclude, even as I said before, that the him in the text, and him that cometh, includeth both these sorts of sinners, and therefore both should freely come.
column10814: But where doth Jesus Christ, in all the word of the New Testament, expressly speak to a returning backslider with words of grace and peace?
column10815: For what you have urged as yet, from the New Testament, is nothing but consequences drawn from this text.
column10816: Indeed it is a full text for carnal ignorant sinners that come, but to me, who am a backslider, it yieldeth but little relief.
column10819: but little encouragement from the text, when it is said, "I will in now wise cast out"!
column10820: What more could have been said?
column10821: What is here omitted that might have been inserted, to make the promise more full and free?
column10822: Nay, take all the promises in the Bible, all the freest promises, with all the variety of expressions of what nature or extent soever, and they can but amount to the expressions of this very promise, "I will in no wise cast out;" I will for nothing, by no means, upon no account, however they have sinned, however they have backslidden, however they have provoked, cast out the coming sinner.
column10825: Thou sayest, Where doth Jesus Christ, in all the words of the New Testament, speak to a returning backslider with words of grace and peace, that is under the name of a backslider?
column10827: Where there is such plenty of examples in receiving backsliders, there is the less need for express words to that intent; one promise, as the text is, with those examples that are annexed, are instead of many promises.
column10828: And besides, I reckon that the act of receiving is of as much, if not of more encouragement, than is a bare promise to receive; for receiving is as the promise, and the fulfilling of it too; so that in the Old Testament thou hast the promise, and in the New, the fulfilling of it; and that in divers examples.
column10831: Peter denied his master, once, twice, thrice, and that with open oath; yet Christ receives him again without any the least hesitation or stick.
column10832: Yea, he slips, stumbles, falls again, in downright dissimulation, and that to the hurt and fall of many others; but neither of this doth Christ make a bar to his salvation, but receives him again at his return, as if he knew nothing of the fault (Gal 2).
column10834: The rest of the disciples, even all of them, did backslide and leave the Lord Jesus in his greatest straits.
column10835: "Then all the disciples forsook him and fled," (Matt 26:56), they returned, as he had foretold, every one to his own, and left him alone; but this also he passes over as a very light matter.
column10836: Not that it was so indeed in itself, but the abundance of grace that was in him did lightly roll it away; for after his resurrection, when first he appeared unto them, he gives them not the least check for their perfidious dealings with him, but salutes them with words of grace, saying, "All hail!
column10837: be not afraid, peace be to you; all power in heaven and earth is given unto me."
column10838: True, he rebuked them for their unbelief, for the which also thou deservest the same.
column10839: For it is unbelief that alone puts Christ and his benefits from us (John 16:52; Matt 28:9-11; Luke 24:39; Mark 16:14).
column10841: The man that after a large profession lay with his father's wife, committed a high transgression, even such a one that at that day was not heard of, no, not among the Gentiles.
column10842: Wherefore this was a desperate backsliding; yet, at his return, he was received, and accepted again to mercy (1 Cor 5:1,2; 2 Cor 2:6-8).
column10844: The thief that stole was bid to steal no more; not at all doubting but that Christ was ready to forgive him this act of backsliding (Eph 4:28).
column10845: Now all these are examples, particular instances of Christ's readiness to receive the backsliders to mercy; and, observe it, examples and proofs that he hath done so are, to our unbelieving hearts, stronger encouragements than bare promises that so he will do.
column10846: But again, the Lord Jesus hath added to these, for the encouragement of returning backsliders, to come to him.
column10848: A call to come, and he will receive them (Rev 2:1-5; 14-16; 20-22; 3:1-3; 15-22).
column10849: Wherefore New Testament backsliders have encouragement to come.
column10851: A declaration of readiness to receive them that come, as here in the text, and in many other places, is plain.
column10852: Therefore, "Set thee up waymarks, make thee high heaps," of the golden grace of the gospel, "set thine heart toward the highway, even the way which thou wentest."
column10853: When thou didst backslide; "turn again, O virgin of Israel, turn again to these thy cities" (Jer 31:21).
column10855: He saith not, and him that talketh, that professeth, that maketh a show, a noise, or the like; but, him that cometh.
column10856: Christ will take leave to judge, who, among the many that make a noise, they be that indeed are coming to him.
column10857: It is not him that saith he comes, nor him of whom others affirm that he comes; but him that Christ himself shall say doth come, that is concerned in this text.
column10858: When the woman that had the bloody issue came to him for cure, there were others as well as she, that made a great bustle about him, that touched, yea, thronged him.
column10859: Ah, but Christ could distinguish this woman from them all; "And he looked round about" upon them all, "to see her that had done this thing" (Mark 5:25-32).
column10860: He was not concerned with the thronging, or touchings of the rest; for theirs were but accidental, or at best, void of that which made her touch acceptable.
column10861: Wherefore Christ must be judge who they be that in truth are coming to him; Every man's ways are right in his own eyes, "but the Lord weigheth the spirits" (Prov 16:2).
column10862: It standeth therefore every one in hand to be certain of their coming to Jesus Christ; for as thy coming is, so shall thy salvation be.
column10863: If thou comest indeed, thy salvation shall be indeed; but if thou comest but in outward appearance, so shall thy salvation be; but of coming, see before, as also afterwards, in the use and application.
column10865: These words to me are also well to be heeded; for by them, as he secureth those that come to him, so also he shows himself unconcerned with those that in their coming rest short, to turn aside to others; for you must know, that every one that comes, comes not to Jesus Christ; some that come, come to Moses, and to his law, and there take up for life; with these Christ is not concerned; with these his promise hath not to do.
column10866: "Christ is become of no effect unto you; whosoever of you are justified by the law, ye are fallen from grace" (Gal 5:4).
column10867: Again, some that came, came no further than to gospel ordinances, and there stay; they came not through them to Christ; with these neither is he concerned; nor will their "Lord, Lord," avail them anything in the great and dismal day.
column10868: A man may come to, and also go from the place and ordinances of worship, and yet not be remembered by Christ.
column10869: "So I saw the wicked buried," said Solomon, "who had come and gone from the place of the holy, and they were forgotten in the city where they had so done; this is also vanity" (Eccl 8:10).
column10871: These words, therefore, are by Jesus Christ very warily put in, and serve for caution and encouragement; for caution, lest we take up in our coming anywhere short of Christ; and for encouragement to those that shall in their coming, come past all; till they come to Jesus Christ.
column10872: "And him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out."
column10873: Reader, if thou lovest thy soul, take this caution kindly at the hands of Jesus Christ.
column10874: Thou seest thy sickness, thy wound, thy necessity of salvation.
column10875: Well, go not to king Jareb, for he cannot heal thee, nor cure thee of thy wound (Hosea 5:13).
column10876: Take the caution, I say, lest Christ, instead of being a Saviour unto thee, becomes a lion, a young lion, to tear thee, and go away (Hosea 5:14).
column10877: There is a coming, but not to the Most High; there is a coming, but not with the whole heart, but as it were feignedly; therefore take the caution kindly (Jer 3:10; Hosea 7:16).
column10878: "And him that cometh TO ME;" Christ as a Saviour will stand alone, because his own arm alone hath brought salvation unto him.
column10879: He will not be joined with Moses, nor suffer John Baptist to be tabernacled by him.
column10880: I say they must vanish, for Christ will stand alone (Luke 9:28-36).
column10881: Yea, God the Father will have it so; therefore they must be parted from him, and a voice from heaven must come to bid the disciples hear only the beloved Son.
column10882: Christ will not suffer any law, ordinance, statute, or judgment, to be partners with him in the salvation of the sinner.
column10883: Nay, he saith not, and him that cometh to my WORD; but, and him that cometh to ME.
column10884: The words of Christ, even his most blessed and free promises, such as this in the text, are not the Saviour of the world; for that is Christ himself, Christ himself only.
column10885: The promises, therefore, are but to encourage the coming sinner to come to Jesus Christ, and not to rest in them, short of salvation by him.
column10887: The man, therefore, that comes aright, casts all things behind his back, and looketh at, nor hath his expectations from ought, but the Son of God alone; as David said, "My soul, wait thou only upon God; for my expectation is from him.
column10888: He only is my rock, and my salvation; he is my defence; I shall not be moved" (Psa 62:5,6).
column10889: His eye is to Christ, his heart is to Christ, and his expectation is from him, from him only.
column10890: Therefore the man that comes to Christ, is one that hath had deep considerations of his own sins, slighting thoughts of his own righteousness, and high thoughts of the blood and righteousness of Jesus Christ; yea, he sees, as I have said, more virtue in the blood of Christ to save him, than there is in all his sins to damn him.
column10891: He therefore setteth Christ before his eyes; there is nothing in heaven or earth, he knows, that can save his soul and secure him from the wrath of God, but Christ; that is, nothing but his personal righteousness and blood.
column10892: [Import of the words IN NO WISE.]
column10893: "And him that cometh to me, I will in no wise cast out."
column10894: IN NO WISE: by these words there is [First,] Something expressed; and [Second,] Something implied.
column10895: First, That which is expressed is Christ Jesus, his unchangeable resolution to save the coming sinner; I will in no wise reject him, or deny him the benefit of my death and righteousness.
column10896: This word, therefore, is like that which he speaks of the everlasting damnation of the sinner in hell-fire; "He shall by no means depart thence;" that is, never, never come out again, no, not to all eternity (Matt 5:26; 25:46).
column10897: So that as he that is condemned into hell-fire hath no ground of hope for his deliverance thence; so him that cometh to Christ, hath no ground to fear he shall ever be cast in thither.
column10898: "Thus saith the Lord, If heaven above can be measured, and the foundations of the earth searched out beneath, I will also cast off all the seed of Israel, for all that they have done, saith the Lord" (Jer 31:37).
column10899: "Thus saith the Lord, If my covenant be not with day and night, and if I have not appointed the ordinances of heaven and earth, then will I cast away the seed of Jacob" (Jer 33:25,26).
column10900: But heaven cannot be measured, nor the foundations of the earth searched out beneath; his covenant is also with day and night, and he hath appointed the ordinances of heaven; therefore he will not cast away the seed of Jacob, who are the coming ones, but will certainly save them from the dreadful wrath to come (Jer 50:4,5).
column10901: By this, therefore, it is manifest, that it was not the greatness of sin, nor the long continuance in it, no, nor yet the backsliding, nor the pollution of thy nature, that can put a bar in against, or be an hindrance of, the salvation of the coming sinner.

column11153: [THE POWER OF CHRIST TO SAVE, OR TO CAST OUT.]

column11524: [COMERS OFTTIMES AFRAID THAT CHRIST WILL NOT RECEIVE THEM.]
column11525: OBSERVATION SECOND.--I come now to the second observation propounded to be spoken to, to wit, That they that are coming to Jesus Christ, are ofttimes heartily afraid that Jesus Christ will not receive them.
column11526: I told you that this observation is implied in the text; and I gather it, First, From the largeness and openness of the promise: "I will in no wise cast out."
column11527: For had there not been a proneness in us to "fear casting out," Christ needed not to have, as it were, waylaid our fear, as he doth by this great and strange expression, "In no wise;" "And him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out."
column11528: There needed not, as I may say, such a promise to be invented by the wisdom of heaven, and worded at such a rate, as it were on purpose to dash in pieces at one blow all the objections of coming sinners, if they were not prone to admit of such objections, to the discouraging of their own souls.
column11529: For this word, "in no wise," cutteth the throat of all objections; and it was dropped by the Lord Jesus for that very end; and to help the faith that is mixed with unbelief.
column11530: And it is, as it were, the sum of all promises; neither can any objection be made upon the unworthiness that thou findest in thee, that this promise will not assoil.
column11531: But I am a great sinner, sayest thou.
column11532: "I will in no wise cast out," says Christ.
column11533: But I am an old sinner, sayest thou.
column11534: "I will in no wise cast out," says Christ.
column11535: But I am a hard-hearted sinner, sayest thou.
column11536: "I will in no wise cast out," says Christ.
column11537: But I am a backsliding sinner, sayest thou.
column11538: "I will in no wise cast out," says Christ.
column11539: But I have served Satan all my days, sayest thou.
column11540: "I will in no wise cast out," says Christ.
column11541: But I have sinned against light, sayest thou.
column11542: "I will in no wise cast out," says Christ.
column11543: But I have sinned against mercy, sayest thou.
column11544: "I will in no wise cast out," says Christ.
column11545: But I have no good thing to bring with me, sayest thou.
column11546: "I will in no wise cast out," says Christ.
column11547: Thus I might go on to the end of things, and show you, that still this promise was provided to answer all objections, and doth answer them.
column11548: But I say, what need it be, if they that are coming to Jesus Christ are not sometimes, yea, oftentimes, heartily afraid, "that Jesus Christ will cast them out?"
column11549: Second, I will give you now two instances that seem to imply the truth of this observation.
column11550: In the ninth of Matthew, at the second verse, you read of a man that was sick of the palsy; and he was coming to Jesus Christ, being borne upon a bed by his friends: he also was coming himself, and that upon another account than any of his friends were aware of; even for the pardon of sins, and the salvation of his soul.
column11551: Now, so soon as ever he was come into the presence of Christ, Christ bids him "be of good cheer."
column11552: It seems then, his heart was fainting; but what was the cause of his fainting?
column11553: Not his bodily infirmity, for the cure of which his friends did bring him to Christ; but the guilt and burden of his sins, for the pardon of which himself did come to him; therefore he proceeds, "Be of good cheer, thy sins be forgiven thee."
column11554: I say, Christ saw him sinking in his mind, about how it would go with his most noble part; and therefore, first, he applies himself to him upon that account.
column11555: For though his friends had faith enough as to the cure of the body, yet he himself had little enough as to the cure of his soul: therefore Christ takes him up as a man falling down, saying, "Son, be of good cheer, thy sins be forgiven thee."
column11556: That about the Prodigal seems pertinent also to this matter: "When he came to himself, he said, How many hired servants of my father's have bread enough and to spare, and I perish with hunger!
column11557: I will arise and go to my father."
column11558: Heartily spoken; but how did he perform his promise?
column11559: I think not so well as he promised to do; and my ground for my thoughts is, because his father, so soon as he was come to him, fell upon his neck and kissed him; implying, methinks, as if the prodigal by this time was dejected in his mind; and therefore his father gives him the most sudden and familiar token of reconciliation.
column11560: And kisses were of old time often used to remove doubts and fears.
column11561: Thus Laban and Esau kiss Jacob.
column11562: Thus Joseph kissed his brethren; and thus also David kissed Absalom (Gen 31:55; 33:1-4; 48:9,10; 2 Sam 14:33).
column11563: It is true, as I said, at first setting out, he spake heartily, as sometimes sinners also do in their beginning to come to Jesus Christ; but might not he, yea, in all probability he had, between the first step he took, and the last, by which he accomplished that journey, many a thought, both this way and that; as whether his father would receive him or no?
column11564: As thus: I said, "I would go to my Father."
column11565: But how, if when I come at him he should ask me, Where I have all this while been?
column11567: Also, if he ask me, What is become of the portion of goods that he gave me?
column11569: If he asks me, Who have been my companions?
column11571: If he also shall ask me, What hath been my preferment in all the time of my absence from him?
column11573: Yea, and if he ask me, Why I came home no sooner?
column11575: Thus, I say, might he reason with himself, and being conscious to himself, that he could give but a bad answer to any of these interrogatories, no marvel if he stood in need first of all of a kiss from his father's lips.
column11576: For had he answered the first in truth, he must say, I have been a haunter of taverns and ale-houses; and as for my portion, I spent it in riotous living; my companions were whores and drabs; as for my preferment, the highest was, that I became a hog-herd; and as for my not coming home till now, could I have made shift to have staid abroad any longer, I had not lain at thy feet for mercy now.
column11577: I say, these things considered, and considering, again, how prone poor man is to give way, when truly awakened, to despondings and heart misgivings, no marvel if he did sink in his mind, between the time of his first setting out, and that of his coming to his Father.
column11578: Third, But, thirdly, methinks I have for the confirmation of this truth the consent of all the saints that are under heaven, to wit, That they that are coming to Jesus Christ, are ofttimes heartily afraid that he will not receive them.
column11580: But what should be the reason?
column11581: I will answer to this question thus: 1.
column11582: It is not for want of the revealed will of God, that manifesteth grounds for the contrary, for of that there is a sufficiency; yea, the text itself hath laid a sufficient foundation for encouragement, for them that are coming to Jesus Christ.
column11583: "And him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out."
column11585: It is not for want of any invitation to come, for that is full and plain.
column11586: "Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest" (Matt 11:28).
column11588: Neither is it for want of a manifestation of Christ's willingness to receive, as those texts above named, with that which follows, declareth, "If any man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink" (John 7:37).
column11590: It is not for want of exceeding great and precious promises to receive them that come.
column11591: "Wherefore come out from among them, and be ye separate, saith the Lord, and touch not the unclean thing, and I will receive you, and will be a Father unto you, and ye shall be my sons and daughters, saith the Lord Almighty" (2 Cor 6:17,18).
column11593: It is not for want of solemn oath and engagement to save them that come.
column11594: "For--because he could swear by no greater, he sware by himself--that by two immutable things, in which it was impossible for God to lie, we might have a strong consolation, who have fled for refuge to lay hold upon the hope set before us" (Heb 6:13-18).
column11596: Neither is it for want of great examples of God's mercy, that have come to Jesus Christ, of which we read most plentifully in the Word.
column11597: Therefore, it must be concluded, it is for want of that which follows.
column11598: [What it is that prevents the coming to Christ.]
column11599: First, It is for want of the knowledge of Christ.
column11600: Thou knowest but little of the grace and kindness that is in the heart of Christ; thou knowest but little of the virtue and merit of his blood; thou knowest but little of the willingness that is in his heart to save thee; and this is the reason of the fear that ariseth in thy heart, and that causeth thee to doubt that Christ will not receive thee.
column11601: Unbelief is the daughter of Ignorance.
column11602: Therefore Christ saith, "O fools, and slow of heart to believe" (Luke 24:25).
column11603: Slowness of heart to believe, flows from thy foolishness in the things of Christ; this is evident to all that are acquainted with themselves, and are seeking after Jesus Christ.
column11604: The more ignorance, the more unbelief.
column11605: The more knowledge of Christ, the more faith.
column11606: "They that know thy name will put their trust in thee" (Psa 9:10).
column11607: He, therefore, that began to come to Christ but the other day, and hath yet but little knowledge of him, he fears that Christ will not receive him.
column11608: But he that hath been longer acquainted with him, he "is strong, and hath overcome the wicked one" (1 John 2:13).
column11609: When Joseph's brethren came into Egypt to buy corn, it is said, "Joseph knew his brethren, but his brethren knew not him."
column11611: Why, great mistrust of heart about their speeding well; especially, if Joseph did but answer them roughly, calling them spies, and questioning their truth and the like.
column11612: And observe it, so long as their ignorance about their brother remained with them, whatsoever Joseph did, still they put the worse sense upon it.
column11613: For instance, Joseph upon a time bids the steward of his house bring them home, to dine with him, to dine even in Joseph's house.
column11614: And how is this resented by them?
column11616: "And the men were afraid, because they were brought unto" their brother "Joseph's house."
column11617: And they said, He seeketh occasion against us, and will fall upon us, and take us for bondmen, and our asses (Gen 42, 43).
column11619: afraid to go to Joseph's house?
column11620: He was their brother; he intended to feast them; to feast them, and to feast with them.
column11622: but they were ignorant that he was their brother.
column11623: And so long as their ignorance lasted, so long their fear terrified them.
column11624: Just thus it is with the sinner that but of late is coming to Jesus Christ.
column11625: He is ignorant of the love and pity that is in Christ to coming sinners.
column11626: Therefore he doubts, therefore he fears, therefore his heart misgives him.
column11627: Coming sinner, Christ inviteth thee to dine and sup with him.
column11628: He inviteth thee to a banquet of wine, yea, to come into his wine-cellar, and his banner over thee shall be love (Rev 3:20; Song 2:5).
column11629: But I doubt it, says the sinner: but, it is answered, he calls thee, invites thee to his banquet, flagons, apples; to his wine, and to the juice of his pomegranate.
column11630: "O, I fear, I doubt, I mistrust, I tremble in expectation of the contrary!"
column11631: Come out of the man, thou dastardly ignorance!
column11632: Be not afraid, sinner, only believe; "He that cometh to Christ he will in no wise cast out."
column11633: Let the coming sinner, therefore, seek after more of the good knowledge of Jesus Christ.
column11634: Press after it, seek it as silver, and dig for it as for hid treasure.
column11635: This will embolden thee; this will make thee wax stronger and stronger.
column11636: "I know whom I have believed," I know him, said Paul; and what follows?
column11637: Why, "and I am persuaded that he is able to keep that which I have committed unto him, against that day" (2 Tim 1:12).
column11638: What had Paul committed to Jesus Christ?
column11639: The answer is, He had committed to him his soul.
column11640: But why did he commit his soul to him?
column11642: He knew him to be faithful, to be kind.
column11643: He knew he would not fail him, nor forsake him; and therefore he laid his soul down at his feet, and committed it to him, to keep against that day.
column11644: But, Second, Thy fears that Christ will not receive thee may be also a consequent of thy earnest and strong desires after thy salvation by him.
column11645: For this I observe, that strong desires to have, are attended with strong fears of missing.
column11646: What man most sets his heart upon, and what his desires are most after, he ofttimes most fears he shall not obtain.
column11647: So the man, the ruler of the synagogue, had a great desire that his daughter should live; and that desire was attended with fear, that she should not.
column11648: Wherefore, Christ saith unto him, "Be not afraid" (Mark 5:36).
column11649: Suppose a young man should have his heart much set upon a virgin to have her to wife, if ever he fears he shall not obtain her, it is when he begins to love; now, thinks he, somebody will step in betwixt my love and the object of it; either they will find fault with my person, my estate, my conditions, or something!
column11650: Now thoughts begin to work; she doth not like me, or something.
column11651: And thus it is with the soul at first coming to Jesus Christ, thou lovest him, and thy love produceth jealousy, and that jealousy ofttimes begets fears.
column11652: Now thou fearest the sins of thy youth, the sins of thine old age, the sins of thy calling, the sins of thy Christian duties, the sins of thine heart, or something; thou thinkest something or other will alienate the heart and affections of Jesus Christ from thee; thou thinkest he sees something in thee, for the sake of which he will refuse thy soul.
column11653: But be content, a little more knowledge of him will make thee take better heart; thy earnest desires shall not be attended with such burning fears; thou shalt hereafter say, "This is my infirmity" (Psa 77:10).
column11654: Thou art sick of love, a very sweet disease, and yet every disease has some weakness attending of it: yet I wish this distemper, if it be lawful to call it so, was more epidemical.
column11655: Die of this disease I would gladly do; it is better than life itself, though it be attended with fears.
column11656: But thou criest, I cannot obtain: well, be not too hasty in making conclusions.
column11657: If Jesus Christ had not put his finger in at the hole of the lock, thy bowels would not have been troubled for him (Song 5:4).
column11658: Mark how the prophet hath it, "They shall walk after the Lord; he shall roar like a lion; when he shall roar, then the children shall tremble from the west, they shall tremble as a bird out of Egypt, and as a dove out of the land of Assyria" (Hosea 11:10,11).
column11659: When God roars (as ofttimes the coming soul hears him roar), what man that is coming can do otherwise than tremble?
column11661: But trembling he comes: "He sprang in, and came trembling, and fell down before Paul and Silas" (Acts 16:29).
column11662: Should you ask him that we mentioned but now, How long is it since you began to fear you should miss of this damsel you love so?
column11663: The answer will be, Ever since I began to love her.
column11664: But did you not fear it before?
column11665: No, nor should I fear it now, but that I vehemently love her.
column11666: Come, sinner, let us apply it: How long is it since thou began to fear that Jesus Christ will not receive thee?
column11667: Thy answer is, Ever since I began to desire that he would save my soul.
column11668: I began to fear, when I began to come; and the more my heart burns in desires after him, the more I feel my heart fear I shall not be saved by him.
column11669: See now, did not I tell thee that thy fears were but the consequence of strong desires?
column11670: Well, fear not, coming sinner, thousands of coming souls are in thy condition, and yet they will get safe into Christ's bosom: "Say," says Christ, "to them that are of a fearful heart, Be strong, fear not; your God will come and save you" (Isa 35:4; 63:1).
column11671: Third, Thy fear that Christ will not receive thee may arise from a sense of thine own unworthiness.
column11672: Thou seest what a poor, sorry, wretched, worthless creature thou art; and seeing this, thou fearest Christ will not receive thee.
column11673: Alas, sayest thou, I am the vilest of all men; a town-sinner, a ringleading sinner!
column11674: I am not only a sinner myself, but have made others twofold worse the children of hell also.
column11675: Besides, now I am under some awakenings and stirrings of mind after salvation, even now I find my heart rebellious, carnal, hard, treacherous, desperate, prone to unbelief, to despair: it forgetteth the Word; it wandereth; it runneth to the ends of the earth.
column11676: There is not, I am persuaded, one in all the world that hath such a desperate wicked heart as mine is; my soul is careless to do good, but none more earnest to do that which is evil.
column11677: Can such a one as I am, live in glory?
column11678: Can a holy, a just, and a righteous God, once think (with honour to his name) of saving such a vile creature as I am?
column11680: Will he show wonders to such a dead dog as I am?
column11682: I am cast out to the loathing of my person, yea, I loath myself; I stink in mine own nostrils.
column11683: How can I then be accepted by a holy and sin-abhorring God?
column11685: Saved I would be; and who is there that would not, were they in my condition?
column11686: Indeed, I wonder at the madness and folly of others, when I see them leap and skip so carelessly about the mouth of hell!
column11687: Bold sinner, how darest thou tempt God, by laughing at the breach of his holy law?
column11689: they are not so bad one way, but I am worse another: I wish myself were anybody but myself; and yet here again, I know not what to wish.
column11690: When I see such as I believe are coming to Jesus Christ, O I bless them!
column11691: But I am confounded in myself, to see how unlike, as I think, I am to every good man in the world.
column11692: They can read, hear, pray, remember, repent, be humble, do everything better than so vile a wretch as I. I, vile wretch, am good for nothing but to burn in hell-fire, and when I think of that, I am confounded too!
column11693: Thus the sense of unworthiness creates and heightens fears in the hearts of them that are coming to Jesus Christ; but indeed it should not; for who needs the physician but the sick?
column11694: or who did Christ come into the world to save, but the chief of sinners?
column11696: Wherefore, the more thou seest thy sins, the faster fly thou to Jesus Christ.
column11697: And let the sense of thine own unworthiness prevail with thee yet to go faster.
column11698: As it is with the man that carrieth his broken arm in a sling to the bone-setter, still as he thinks of his broken arm, and as he feels the pain and anguish, he hastens his pace to the man.
column11699: And if Satan meets thee, and asketh, Whither goest thou?
column11700: tell him thou art maimed, and art going to the Lord Jesus.
column11701: If he objects thine own unworthiness, tell him, That even as the sick seeketh the physician; as he that hath broken bones seeks him that can set them; so thou art going to Jesus Christ for cure and healing for thy sin sick soul.
column11702: But it ofttimes happeneth to him that flies for his life, he despairs of escaping, and therefore delivers himself up into the hand of the pursuer.
column11703: But up, up, sinner; be of good cheer, Christ came to save the unworthy ones: be not faithless, but believe.
column11704: Come away, man, the Lord Jesus calls thee, saying, "And him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out."
column11706: Thy fear that Christ will not receive thee, may arise from a sense of the exceeding mercy of being saved; sometimes salvation is in the eyes of him that desires so great, so huge, so wonderful a thing, that the very thoughts of the excellency of it, engenders unbelief about obtaining it, in the heart of those that unfeignedly desire it.
column11707: "Seemeth it to you," saith David, "a light thing to be a king's son-in-law?"
column11709: So the thoughts of the greatness and glory of the thing propounded, as heaven, eternal life, eternal glory, to be with God, and Christ, and angels; these are great things, things too good, saith the soul that is little in his own eyes; things too rich, saith the soul that is truly poor in spirit, for me.
column11710: Besides, the Holy Ghost hath a way to greaten heavenly things to the understanding of the coming sinner; yea, and at the same time to greaten, too, the sin and unworthiness of that sinner.
column11711: Now the soul staggeringly wonders, saying, What!
column11712: to be made like angels, like Christ, to live in eternal bliss, joy, and felicity!
column11713: This is for angels, and for them that can walk like angels!
column11714: If a prince, a duke, an earl, should send (by the hand of his servant) for some poor, sorry, beggarly scrub, to take her for his master to wife, and the servant should come and say, My lord and master, such an one hath sent me to thee, to take thee to him to wife; he is rich, beautiful, and of excellent qualities; he is loving, meek, humble, well-spoken, &c. What now would this poor, sorry, beggarly creature think?
column11716: or how would she frame an answer?
column11717: When king David sent to Abigail upon this account, and though she was a rich woman, yet she said, "Behold, let thine handmaid be a servant to wash the feet of the servants of my lord" (1 Sam 25:40,41).
column11718: She was confounded, she could not well tell what to say, the offer was so great, beyond what could in reason be expected.
column11719: But suppose this great person should second his suit, and send to this sorry creature again, what would she say now?
column11720: Would she not say, You mock me?
column11721: But what if he affirms that he is in good earnest, and that his lord must have her to wife; yea, suppose he should prevail upon her to credit his message, and to address herself for her journey; yet, behold every thought of her pedigree confounds her; also her sense of want of beauty makes her ashamed; and if she doth but think of being embraced, the unbelief that is mixed with that thought whirls her into tremblings; and now she calls herself fool, for believing the messenger, and thinks not to go; if she thinks of being bold, she blushes; and the least thought that she shall be rejected, when she comes at him, makes her look as if she would give up the ghost.
column11722: And is it a wonder, then, to see a soul that is drowned in the sense of glory and a sense of its own nothingness, to be confounded in itself, and to fear that the glory apprehended is too great, too good, and too rich, for such an one?
column11723: That thing, heaven and eternal glory, is so great, and I that would have it, so small, so sorry a creature, that the thoughts of obtaining it confounds me.
column11724: Thus, I say, doth the greatness of the things desired, quite dash and overthrow the mind of the desirer.
column11727: it is too great a mercy!
column11728: But, coming sinner, let me reason with thee.
column11729: Thou sayest, it is too big, too great.
column11730: Well, will things that are less satisfy thy soul?
column11731: Will a less thing than heaven, than glory and eternal life, answer thy desires?
column11732: No, nothing less; and yet I fear they are too big, and too good for me, ever to obtain.
column11733: Well, as big and as good as they are, God giveth them to such as thou; they are not too big for God to give; no, not too big to give freely.
column11734: Be content; let God give like himself; he is that eternal God, and giveth like himself.
column11735: When kings give, they do not use to give as poor men do.
column11736: Hence it is said, that Nabal made a feast in his house like the feast of a king; and again, "All these things did Araunah, as a king, give unto David" (1 Sam 25:36; 2 Sam 24:23).
column11737: Now, God is a great king, let him give like a king; nay, let him give like himself, and do thou receive like thyself.
column11738: He hath all, and thou hast nothing.
column11739: God told his people of old, that he would save them in truth and in righteousness, and that they should return to, and enjoy the land, which before, for their sins, had spewed them out; and then adds, under a supposition of their counting the mercy too good, or too big, "If it be marvellous in the eyes of the remnant of this people in these days, should it also be marvellous in mine eyes?
column11741: As who should say, they are now in captivity, and little in their own eyes; therefore they think the mercy of returning to Canaan is a mercy too marvellously big for them to enjoy; but if it be so in their eyes, it is not so in mine; I will do for them like God, if they will but receive my bounty like sinners.
column11742: Coming sinner, God can give his heavenly Canaan, and the glory of it, unto thee; yea, none ever had them but as a gift, a free gift.
column11743: He hath given us his Son, "How shall he not with him also freely give us all things?"
column11745: It was not the worthiness of Abraham, or Moses, or David or Peter, or Paul, but the mercy of God, that made them inheritors of heaven.
column11746: If God thinks thee worthy, judge not thyself unworthy; but take it, and be thankful.
column11747: And it is a good sign he intends to give thee, if he hath drawn out thy heart to ask.
column11748: "Lord, thou hast heard the desire of the humble; thou wilt prepare their heart; thou wilt cause thine ear to hear" (Psa 10:17).
column11749: When God is said to incline his ear, it implies an intention to bestow the mercy desired.
column11750: Take it therefore; thy wisdom will be to receive, not sticking at thy own unworthiness.
column11751: It is said, "He raiseth up the poor out of the dust, and lifteth up the beggar from the dunghill, to set them among princes, and to make them inherit the throne of glory."
column11752: Again, "He raiseth up the poor out of the dust, and lifteth the needy out of the dunghill, that he may set him with princes, even with the princes of his people" (1 Sam 2:8; Psa 113:7,8).
column11753: You see also when God made a wedding for his Son, he called not the great, nor the rich, nor the mighty; but the poor, the maimed, the halt, and the blind (Matt 12; Luke 14).
column11755: Thy fears that Christ will not receive thee may arise from the hideous roaring of the devil, who pursues thee.
column11756: He that hears him roar, must be a mighty Christian, if he can at that time deliver himself from fear.
column11757: He is called a roaring lion; and then to allude to that in Isaiah, "If one look" into them, they have "darkness and sorrow, and the light is darkened in the heavens thereof" (1 Peter 5:8; Isa 5:3).
column11759: --There are two things among many that Satan useth to roar out after them that are coming to Jesus Christ.
column11763: That they have sinned the sin against the Holy Ghost.
column11764: To both these I answer briefly-- 1.
column11766: --Touching election, out of which thou fearest thou art excluded.
column11767: Why, coming sinner, even the text itself affordeth thee help against this doubt, and that by a double argument.
column11769: That coming to Christ is by virtue of the gift, promise, and drawing of the Father; but thou art a-coming; therefore God hath given thee, promised thee, and is drawing thee to Jesus Christ.
column11770: Coming sinner, hold to this; and when Satan beginneth to roar again, answer, But I feel my heart moving after Jesus Christ; but that would not be, if it were not given by promise, and drawing to Christ by the power of the Father.
column11772: Jesus Christ hath promised, "That him that cometh to him he will in no wise cast out."
column11773: And if he hath said it, will he not make it good, I mean even thy salvation?
column11774: For, as I have said already, not to cast out, is to receive and admit to the benefit of salvation.
column11775: If then the Father hath given thee, as is manifest by thy coming; and if Christ will receive thee, thou coming soul, as it is plain he will, because he hath said, "He will in no wise cast out;" then be confident, and let those conclusions, that as naturally flow from the text as light from the sun, or water from the fountain, stay thee.
column11776: If Satan therefore objecteth, But thou art not elected; answer, But I am coming, Satan, I am coming; and that I could not be, but that the Father draws me; and I am coming to such a Lord Jesus, as will in no wise cast me out.
column11777: Further, Satan, were I not elect, the Father would not draw me, nor would the Son so graciously open his bosom to me.
column11778: I am persuaded, that not one of the nonelect shall ever be able to say, no, not in the day of judgment, I did sincerely come to Jesus Christ.
column11779: Come they may, feignedly, as Judas and Simon Magus did; but that is not our question.
column11780: Therefore, O thou honest-hearted coming sinner, be not afraid, but come.
column11782: [Of the sin against the Holy Ghost.]
