column12045: It is not enough to forsake one if thou wilt come to Jesus Christ; because the other will keep thee from him.
column12046: Suppose a man forsakes his wicked ways, his debauched and filthy life; yet if these thoughts, that Jesus Christ will not receive him, be entertained and nourished in his heart; these thoughts will keep him from coming to Jesus Christ.
column12047: Sinner, coming sinner, art thou for coming to Jesus Christ?
column12050: So I do, says the sinner.
column12051: Why comest thou then so slowly?
column12056: Art thou not willing to come faster?
column12058: Well, prithee be plain with me, and tell me the reason and ground of thy discouragement.
column12059: Why, says the sinner, though God forbids me not, and though I am willing to come faster, yet there naturally ariseth this, and that, and the other thought in my heart, that hinders my speed to Jesus Christ.
column12060: Sometimes I think I am not chosen; sometimes I think I am not called; sometimes I think I am come too late; and sometimes I think I know not what it is to come.
column12061: Also one while I think I have no grace; and then again, that I cannot pray; and then again, I think that I am a very hypocrite.
column12062: And these things keep me from coming to Jesus Christ.
column12063: Look ye now, did not I tell you so?
column12064: There are thoughts yet remaining in the heart, even of those who have forsaken their wicked ways; and with those thoughts they are more plagued than with anything else; because they hinder their coming to Jesus Christ; for the sin of unbelief, which is the original of all these thoughts, is that which besets a coming sinner more easily, than doth his ways (Heb 12:1-4).
column12065: But now, since Jesus Christ commands thee to forsake these thoughts, forsake them, coming sinner; and if thou forsake them not, thou transgressest the commands of Christ, and abidest thine own tormentor, and keepest thyself from establishment in grace.
column12066: "If ye will not believe, surely ye shall not be established" (Isa 7:9).
column12067: Thus you see how Jesus Christ setteth himself against such thoughts, that any way discourage the coming sinner; and thereby truly vindicates the doctrine we have in hand; to wit, that Jesus Christ would not have them, that in truth are coming to him, once think that he will cast them out.
column12068: "And him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out."
column12070: I come now to the reasons of the observation.
column12072: If Jesus Christ should allow thee once to think that he will cast thee out, he must allow thee to think that he will falsify his word; for he hath said, "I will in no wise cast out."
column12073: But Christ would not that thou shouldst count him as one that will falsify his word; for he saith of himself, "I am the truth;" therefore he would not that any that in truth are coming to him, should once think that he will cast them out.
column12075: If Jesus Christ should allow the sinner that in truth is coming to him, once to think that he will cast him out, then he must allow, and so countenance the first appearance of unbelief; the which he counteth his greatest enemy, and against which he hast bent even his holy gospel.
column12076: Therefore Jesus Christ would not that they that in truth are coming to him, should once think that he will cast them out.
column12079: If Jesus Christ should allow the coming sinner once to think that he will cast him out; then he must allow him to make a question, Whether he is willing to receive his Father's gift; for the coming sinner is his Father's gift; as also says the text; but he testifieth, "All that the Father giveth me shall come to me; and him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out."
column12080: Therefore Jesus Christ would not have him, that in truth is coming to him, once to think that he will cast him out.
column12082: If Jesus Christ should allow them once to think, that indeed are coming to him, that he will cast them out, he must allow them to think that he will despise and reject the drawing of his Father.
column12083: For no man can come to him but whom the Father draweth.
column12084: But it would be high blasphemy, and damnable wickedness once to imagine thus.
column12085: Therefore, Jesus Christ would not have him that cometh once think that he will cast him out.
column12087: If Jesus Christ should allow those that indeed are coming to him, once to think that he will cast them out, he must allow them to think that he will be unfaithful to the trust and charge that his Father hath committed to him; which is to save, and not to lose anything of that which he hath given unto him to save (John 6:39).
column12088: But the Father hath given him a charge to save the coming sinner; therefore it cannot be, that he should allow, that such an one should once think that he will cast him out.
column12090: If Jesus Christ should allow that they should once think that are coming to him, that he will cast them out, then he must allow them to think that he will be unfaithful to his office of priesthood; for, as by the first part of it, he paid price for, and ransomed souls, so by the second part thereof, he continually maketh intercession to God for them that come (Heb 7:25).
column12091: But he cannot allow us to question his faithful execution of his priesthood.
column12092: Therefore he cannot allow us once to think that the coming sinner shall be cast out.
column12094: If Jesus Christ should allow us once to think that the coming sinner shall be cast out, then he must allow us to question his will, or power, or merit to save.
column12095: But he cannot allow us once to question any of these; therefore not once to think, that the coming sinner shall be cast out.
column12097: He cannot allow them to question his will; for he saith in the text, "I WILL in no wise cast out."
column12099: He cannot allow us to question his power; for the Holy Ghost saith HE IS ABLE to save to the uttermost them that come.
column12101: He cannot allow them to question the efficacy of his merit; for the blood of Christ cleanseth the comer from all sin, (1 John 1:7), therefore he cannot allow that he that is coming to him should once think that he will cast them out.
column12103: If Jesus Christ should allow the coming sinner once to think that he will cast him out, he must allow him to give the lie to the manifest testimony of the Father, Son, and Spirit; yea, to the whole gospel contained in Moses, the prophets, the book of Psalms, and that commonly called the New Testament.
column12104: But he cannot allow of this; therefore, not that the coming sinner should once think that he will cast him out.
column12106: Lastly, If Jesus Christ should allow him that is coming to him, once to think that he will cast him out, he must allow him to question his Father's oath, which he in truth and righteousness hath taken, that they might have a strong consolation, who have fled for refuge to Jesus Christ.
column12107: But he cannot allow this; therefore he cannot allow that the coming sinner should once think that he will cast him out (Heb 6).
column12109: I come now to make some GENERAL USE AND APPLICATION OF THE WHOLE, and so to draw towards a conclusion.
column12110: USE FIRST.--The first use--A USE OF INFORMATION; and, First, It informeth us that men by nature are far off from Christ.
column12111: Let me a little improve this use, by speaking to these three questions.
column12113: Where is he that is coming [but has not come], to Jesus Christ?
column12115: What is he that is not coming to Jesus Christ?
column12117: Whither is he to go that cometh not to Jesus Christ?
column12122: He is far from God, he is without him, even alienate from him both in his understanding, will, affections, judgment, and conscience (Eph 2:12; 4:18).
column12124: He is far from Jesus Christ, who is the only deliverer of men from hell fire (Psa 73:27).
column12126: He is far from the work of the Holy Ghost, the work of regeneration, and a second creation, without which no man shall see the kingdom of heaven (John 3:3).
column12128: He is far more righteous, 19 from that righteousness that should make him acceptable in God's sight (Isa 46:12,13).
column12130: He is under the power and dominion of sin; sin reigneth in and over him; it dwelleth in every faculty of his soul, and member of his body; so that from head to foot there is no place clean (Isa 1:6; Rom 3:9-18).
column12132: He is in the pest-house with Uzziah and excluded the camp of Israel with the lepers (2 Chron 26:21; Num 5:2; Job 36:14).
column12135: He is "in the gall of bitterness, and in the bond of iniquity" (Acts 8:28).
column12137: He is "in sin," "in the flesh," "in death," "in the snare of the devil," and is "taken captive by him at his will" (1 Cor 15:17; Rom 8:8; 1 John 3:14; 2 Tim 2:26).
column12139: He is under the curse of the law, and the devil dwells in him, and hath the mastery of him (Gal 3:13; Eph 2:2,3; Acts 26:18).
column12141: He is in darkness, and walketh in darkness, and knows not whither he goes; for darkness has blinded his eyes.
column12143: He is in the broad way that leadeth to destruction; and holding on, he will assuredly go in at the broad gate, and so down the stairs to hell.
column12145: What is he that cometh not to Jesus Christ?
column12148: He is counted one of God's enemies (Luke 19:14; Rom 8:7).
column12150: He is a child of the devil, and of hell; for the devil begat him, as to his sinful nature, and hell must swallow him at last, because he cometh not to Jesus Christ (John 8:44; 1 John 3:8; Matt 23:15; Psa 9:17).
column12152: He is a child of wrath, an heir of it; it is his portion, and God will repay it him to his face (Eph 2:1-3; Job 21:29-31).
column12154: He is a self-murderer; he wrongeth his own soul, and is one that loveth death (Prov 1:18; 8:36).
column12156: He is a companion for devils and damned men (Prov 21:16; Matt 25:41).
column12158: Whither is he like to go that cometh not to Jesus Christ?
column12161: He that cometh not to him, is like to go further from him; so every sin is a step further from Jesus Christ (Hosea 11).
column12163: As he is in darkness, so he is like to go on in it; for Christ is the light of the world, and he that comes not to him, walketh in darkness (John 8:12).
column12165: He is like to be removed at last as far from God, and Christ, and heaven, and all felicity, as an infinite God can remove him (Matt 12:41).
column12166: But, Second, This doctrine of coming to Christ informeth us where poor destitute sinners may find life for their souls, and that is in Christ.
column12167: This life is in his Son; he that hath the Son, hath life.
column12168: And again, "Whoso findeth me findeth life, and shall obtain favour of the Lord" (Prov 8:35).
column12169: Now, for further enlargement, I will also here propound three more questions: 1.
column12175: What life is in Jesus Christ?
column12178: There is justifying life in Christ.
column12179: Man by sin is dead in law; and Christ only can deliver him by his righteousness and blood from this death into a state of life.
column12180: "For God sent his Son into the world, that we might live through him" (1 John 4:9).
column12181: That is, through the righteousness which he should accomplish, and the death that he should die.
column12183: There is eternal life in Christ; life that is endless; life for ever and ever.
column12184: "He hath given us eternal life, and this life is in his Son" (1 John 5:11).
column12185: Now, justification and eternal salvation being both in Christ, and nowhere else to be had for men, who would not come to Jesus Christ?
column12187: I answer, Poor, helpless, miserable sinners.
column12189: Such as are willing to have it.
column12190: "Whosoever will, let him take the water of life" (Rev 22:17).
column12193: "I will give unto him that is athirst of the fountain of the water of life" (Rev 21:6).
column12195: He that is weary of his sins.
column12196: "This is the rest wherewith ye may cause the weary to rest; and this is the refreshing" (Isa 28:12).
column12198: He that is poor and needy.
column12199: "He shall spare the poor and needy, and shall save the souls of the needy" (Psa 72:13).
column12201: He that followeth after him, crieth for life.
column12202: "He that followeth me shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life" (John 8:12).
column12204: Upon what terms may he have this life?
column12209: Let him take the water of life freely.
column12210: I will give him of the fountain of the water of life freely.
column12211: "And when they had nothing to pay, he frankly forgave them both" (Luke 7:42).
column12212: Freely, without money, or without price.
column12214: every one that thirsteth, come ye to the waters, and he that hath no money, come ye, buy and eat; yea, come, buy wine and milk without money and without price" (Isa 55:1).
column12218: Come, then, and regard not your stuff; for all the good that is in Christ is offered to the coming sinner, without money and without price.
column12219: He has life to give away to such as want it, and that hath not a penny to purchase it; and he will give it freely.
column12220: Oh what a blessed condition is the coming sinner in!
column12221: But, Third, This doctrine of coming to Jesus Christ for life, informeth us, that it is to be had nowhere else.
column12222: Might it be had anywhere else, the text, and him that spoke it, would be but little set by; for what greater matter is there in "I will in no wise cast out," if another stood by that could receive them?
column12223: But here appears the glory of Christ, that none but he can save.
column12224: And here appears his love, that though none can save but he, yet he is not coy in saving.
column12225: "But him that comes to me," says he, "I will in no wise cast out."
column12226: That none can save but Jesus Christ, is evident from Acts 4:12: "Neither is there salvation in any other;" and "he hath given to us eternal life, and this life is in his Son" (1 John 5:11).
column12227: If life could have been had anywhere else, it should have been in the law.
column12228: But it is not in the law; for by the deeds of the law, no man living shall be justified; and if not justified, then no life.
column12229: Therefore life is nowhere to be had but in Jesus Christ (Gal 3).
column12231: But why would God so order it, that life should be had nowhere else but in Jesus Christ?
column12233: There is reason for it, and that both with respect to God and us.
column12237: That it might be in a way of justice as well as mercy.
column12238: And in a way of justice it could not have been, if it had not been by Christ; because he, and he only, was able to answer the demand of the law, and give for sin what the justice thereof required.
column12239: All angels had been crushed down to hell for ever, had that curse been laid upon them for our sins, which was laid upon Jesus Christ; but it was laid upon him, and he bare it; and answered the penalty, and redeemed his people from under it, with that satisfaction to Divine justice that God himself doth now proclaim, That he is faithful and just to forgive us, if by faith we shall venture to Jesus, and trust to what he has done for life (Rom 3:24-26; John 1:4).
column12241: Life must be by Jesus Christ, that God might be adored and magnified, for finding out this way.
column12242: This is the Lord's doings, that in all things he might be glorified through Jesus Christ our Lord.
column12244: It must be by Jesus Christ, that life might be at God's dispose, who hath great pity for the poor, the lowly, the meek, the broken in heart, and for them that others care not for (Psa 34:6; 138:6; 25; 51:17; 147:3).
column12246: Life must be in Christ, to cut off boasting from the lips of men.
column12247: This also is the apostle's reason in Romans 3:19,27 (Eph 2:8-10).
column12249: Life must be in Jesus Christ with respect to us.
column12251: That we might have it upon the easiest terms, to wit, freely: as a gift, not as wages.
column12252: Was it in Moses' hand, we should come hardly at it.
column12253: Was it in the pope's hand, we should pay soundly for it.
column12254: 20 But thanks be to God, it is in Christ, laid up in him, and by him to be communicated to sinners upon easy terms, even for receiving, accepting, and embracing with thanksgiving; as the Scriptures plainly declare (John 1:11,12; 2 Cor 11:4; Heb 11:13; Col 3:13-15).
column12256: Life is in Christ FOR US, that it might not be upon so brittle a foundation, as indeed it would had it been anywhere else.
column12257: The law itself is weak because of us, as to this.
column12258: But Christ is a tried stone, a sure foundation, one that will not fail to bear thy burden, and to receive thy soul, coming sinner.
column12260: Life is in Christ, that it might be sure to all the seed.
column12262: the best of us, was life left in our hand, to be sure we should forfeit it, over, and over, and over; or, was it in any other hand, we should, by our often backslidings, so offend him, that at last he would shut up his bowels in everlasting displeasure against us.
column12263: But now it is in Christ, it is with one that can pity, pray for, pardon, yea, multiply pardons; it is with one that can have compassion upon us, when we are out of the way; with one that hath an heart to fetch us again, when we are gone astray; with one that can pardon without upbraiding.
column12264: Blessed be God, that life is in Christ!
column12265: For now it is sure to all the seed.
column12266: But, Fourth, This doctrine of coming to Jesus Christ for life informs us of the evil of unbelief; that wicked thing that is the only or chief hindrance to the coming sinner.
column12268: Doth it say, "and him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out?"
column12269: Then what an evil is that that keepeth sinners from coming to Jesus Christ!
column12270: And that evil is unbelief: for by faith we come; by unbelief we keep away.
column12271: Therefore it is said to be that by which a soul is said to depart from God; because it was that which at first caused the world to go off from him, and that also that keeps them from him to this day.
column12272: And it doth it the more easily, because it doth it with a wile.
column12274: --This sin may be called the white devil, for it oftentimes, in its mischievous doings in the soul, shows as if it was an angel of light: yea, it acteth like a counsellor of heaven.
column12275: Therefore a little to discourse of this evil disease.
column12277: It is that sin, above all others, that hath some show of reason in its attempts.
column12278: For it keeps the soul from Christ by pretending its present unfitness and unpreparedness; as want of more sense of sin, want of more repentance, want of more humility, want of a more broken heart.
column12280: It is the sin that most suiteth with the conscience: the conscience of the coming sinner tells him that he hath nothing good; that he stands inditeable for ten thousand talents; that he is a very ignorant, blind, and hard-hearted sinner, unworthy to be once taken notice of by Jesus Christ.
column12281: And will you, says Unbelief, in such a case as you now are, presume to come to Jesus Christ?
column12283: It is the sin that most suiteth with our sense of feeling.
column12284: The coming sinner feels the workings of sin, of all manner of sin and wretchedness in his flesh; he also feels the wrath and judgment of God due to sin, and ofttimes staggers under it.
column12285: Now, says Unbelief, you may see you have no grace; for that which works in you is corruption.
column12286: You may also perceive that God doth not love you, because the sense of his wrath abides upon you.
column12287: Therefore, how can you bear the face to come to Jesus Christ?
column12289: It is that sin, above all others, that most suiteth with the wisdom of our flesh.
column12290: The wisdom of our flesh thinks it prudent to question awhile, to stand back awhile, to hearken to both sides awhile; and not to be rash, sudden, or unadvised, in too bold a presuming upon Jesus Christ.
column12291: And this wisdom unbelief falls in with.
column12293: It is that sin, above all other, that continually is whispering the soul in the ear with mistrusts of the faithfulness of God, in keeping promise to them that come to Jesus Christ for life.
column12294: It also suggests mistrust about Christ's willingness to receive it, and save it.
column12295: And no sin can do this so artificially as unbelief.
column12297: It is also that sin which is always at hand to enter an objection against this or that promise that by the Spirit of God is brought to our heart to comfort us; and if the poor coming sinner is not aware of it, it will, by some evasion, slight, trick, or cavil, quickly wrest from him the promise again, and he shall have but little benefit of it.
column12299: It is that, above all other sins, that weakness our prayers, our faith, our love, our diligence, our hope, and expectations: it even taketh the heart away from God in duty.
column12301: Lastly, This sin, as I have said even now, it appeareth in the soul with so many sweet pretences to safety and security, that it is, as it were, counsel sent from heaven; bidding the soul be wise, wary, considerate, well-advised, and to take heed of too rash a venture upon believing.
column12302: Be sure, first, that God loves you; take hold of no promise until you are forced by God unto it; neither be you sure of your salvation; doubt it still, though the testimony of the Lord has been often confirmed in you.
column12303: Live not by faith, but by sense; and when you can neither see nor feel, then fear and mistrust, then doubt and question all.
column12304: This is the devilish counsel of unbelief, which is so covered over with specious pretences, that the wisest Christian can hardly shake off these reasonings.
column12305: [Qualities of unbelief as opposed to faith.]
column12307: Let me here give thee, Christian reader, a more particular description of the qualities of unbelief, by opposing faith unto it, in these twenty-five particulars:-- 1.
column12308: Faith believeth the Word of God; but unbelief questioneth the certainty of the same (Psa 106:24).
column12310: Faith believeth the Word, because it is true; but unbelief doubteth thereof, because it is true (1 Tim 4:3; John 8:45).
column12312: Faith sees more in a promise of God to help, than in all other things to hinder; but unbelief, notwithstanding God's promise, saith, How can these things be?
column12315: Faith will make thee see love in the heart of Christ, when with his mouth he giveth reproofs; but unbelief will imagine wrath in his heart, when with his mouth and Word he saith he loves us (Matt 15:22,28; Num 13; 2 Chron 14:3).
column12317: Faith will help the soul to wait, though God defers to give; but unbelief will take huff and throw up all, if God makes any tarrying (Psa 25:5; Isa 8:17; 2 Kings 6:33; Psa 106:13,14).
column12319: Faith will give comfort in the midst of fears; but unbelief causeth fears in the midst of comfort (2 Chron 20:20,21; Matt 8:26; Luke 24:26,27).
column12321: Faith will suck sweetness out of God's rod; but unbelief can find no comfort in his greatest mercies (Psa 23:4; Num 21).
column12323: Faith maketh great burdens light; but unbelief maketh light ones intolerably heavy (2 Cor 4:1; 14-18; Mal 1:12,13).
column12325: Faith helpeth us when we are down; but unbelief throws us down when we are up (Micah 7:8-10; Heb 4:11).
column12327: Faith bringeth us near to God when we are far from him; but unbelief puts us far from God when we are near to him (Heb 10:22; 3:12,13).
column12329: Where faith reigns, it declareth men to be the friends of God; but where unbelief reigns, it declareth them to be his enemies (John 3:23; Heb 3:18; Rev 21:8).
column12331: Faith putteth a man under grace; but unbelief holdeth him under wrath (Rom 3:24-26; 14:6; Eph 2:8; John 3:36; 1 John 5:10; Heb 3:17; Mark 16:16).
column12333: Faith purifieth the heart; but unbelief keepeth it polluted and impure (Acts 15:9; Titus 1:15,16).
column12335: By faith, the righteousness of Christ is imputed to us; but by unbelief, we are shut up under the law to perish (Rom 4:23,24; 11:32; Gal 3:23).
column12337: Faith maketh our work acceptable to God through Christ; but whatsoever is of unbelief is sin.
column12338: For without faith it is impossible to please him (Heb 11:4; Rom 14:23; Heb 6:6).
column12340: Faith giveth us peace and comfort in our souls; but unbelief worketh trouble and tossings, like the restless waves of the sea (Rom 5:1; James 1:6).
column12342: Faith maketh us to see preciousness in Christ; but unbelief sees no form, beauty, or comeliness in him (1 Peter 2:7; Isa 53:2,3).
column12344: By faith we have our life in Christ's fullness; but by unbelief we starve and pine away (Gal 2:20).
column12346: Faith gives us the victory over the law, sin, death, the devil, and all evils; but unbelief layeth us obnoxious to them all (1 John 5:4,5; Luke 12:46).
column12348: Faith will show us more excellency in things not seen, than in them that are; but unbelief sees more in things that are seen, than in things that will be hereafter;.
column12351: Faith makes the ways of God pleasant and admirable; but unbelief makes them heavy and hard (Gal 5:6; 1 Cor 12:10,11; John 6:60; Psa 2:3).
column12353: By faith Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob possessed the land of promise; but because of unbelief, neither Aaron, nor Moses, nor Miriam could get thither (Heb 11:9; 3:19).
column12355: By faith the children of Israel passed through the Red Sea; but by unbelief the generality of them perished in the wilderness (Heb 11:29; Jude 5).
column12357: By faith Gideon did more with three hundred men, and a few empty pitchers, than all the twelve tribes could do, because they believed not God (Judg 7:16-22; Num 14:11,14).
column12359: By faith Peter walked on the water; but by unbelief he began to sink (Matt 14:28-30).
column12360: Thus might many more be added, which, for brevity's sake, I omit; beseeching every one that thinketh he hath a soul to save, or be damned, to take heed of unbelief; lest, seeing there is a promise left us of entering into his rest, any of us by unbelief should indeed come short of it.
column12362: The second use--A USE OF EXAMINATION.
column12363: We come now to a use of examination.
column12364: Sinner, thou hast heard of the necessity of coming to Christ; also of the willingness of Christ to receive the coming soul; together with the benefit that they by him shall have that indeed come to him.
column12365: Put thyself now upon this serious inquiry, Am I indeed come to Jesus Christ?
column12366: Motives plenty I might here urge, to prevail with thee to a conscientious performance of this duty.
column12368: Thou art in sin, in the flesh, in death, in the snare of the devil, and under the curse of the law, if you are not coming to Jesus Christ.
column12370: There is no way to be delivered from these, but by coming to Jesus Christ.
column12372: If thou comest, Jesus Christ will receive thee, and will in no wise cast thee out.
column12374: Thou wilt not repent it in the day of judgment, if now thou comest to Jesus Christ.
column12376: But thou wilt surely mourn at last, if now thou shalt refuse to come.
column12378: And lastly, Now thou hast been invited to come; now will thy judgment be greater, and thy damnation more fearful, if thou shalt yet refuse, than if thou hadst never heard of coming to Christ.
column12380: But we hope we are come to Jesus Christ.
column12382: It is well if it proves so.
column12383: But lest thou shouldst speak without ground, and so fall unawares into hell-fire, let us examine a little.
column12384: First, Art thou indeed come to Jesus Christ?
column12385: What hast thou left behind thee?
column12386: What didst thou come away from, in thy coming to Jesus Christ?
column12387: When Lot came out of Sodom, he left the Sodomites behind him (Gen 19).
column12388: When Abraham came out of Chaldea, he left his country and kindred behind him (Gen 12; Acts 7).
column12389: When Ruth came to put her trust under the wings of the Lord God of Israel, she left her father and mother, her gods, and the land of her nativity, behind her (Ruth 1:15-17; 2:11,12).
column12390: When Peter came to Christ, he left his nets behind him (Matt 4:20).
column12391: When Zaccheus came to Christ, he left the receipt of custom behind him (Luke 19).
column12392: When Paul came to Christ, he left his own righteousness behind him (Phil 3:7,8).
column12393: When those that used curious arts came to Jesus Christ, they took their curious books and burned them; though, in another man's eye, they were counted worth fifty thousand pieces of silver (Acts 19:18-20).
column12395: Hast thou left thy darling sins, thy Sodomitish pleasures, thy acquaintance and vain companions, thy unlawful gain, thy idol-gods, thy righteousness, and thy unlawful curious arts, behind thee?
column12396: If any of these be with thee, and thou with them, in thy heart and life, thou art not yet come to Jesus Christ.
column12397: Second, Art thou come to Jesus Christ?
column12398: Prithee tell me what moved thee to come to Jesus Christ?
column12399: Men do not usually come or go to this or that place, before they have a moving cause, or rather a cause moving them thereto.
column12400: No more do they come to Jesus Christ--I do not say, before they have a cause, but--before that cause moveth them to come.
column12402: Hast thou a cause moving thee to come?
column12403: To be at present in a state of condemnation, is cause sufficient for men to come to Jesus Christ for life.

column12772: JUSTIFICATION BY AN IMPUTED RIGHTEOUSNESS JUSTIFICATION is to be diversly taken in the Scripture.
column12773: Sometimes it is taken for the justification of persons; sometimes for the justification of actions; and sometimes for the justification of the person and action too.
column12774: It is taken for the justification of persons, and that, as to justification with God; or, as to justification with men.

column12776: As to justification with men; that is, when a man stands clear and quit from just ground of reprehension with them.

column13559: And were I to argue against the pretended sufficiency of man's own righteousness, I would choose to frame mine argument upon such a place as this--'The hearers of the law are not just before God'; therefore the breakers of the law are not just before God; not just, I say, by the law; but all have sinned and broken the law; therefore none by the law are just before God.
column13560: For if all stand guilty of sin by the law, then that law that judgeth them sinners cannot justify them before God.
column13561: And what if the apostle had said, 'Blessed are they that continue in all things,' instead of pronouncing a curse for the contrary, the conclusion had been the same; for where the blessing is pronounced, he is not the better that breaks the condition; and where the curse is pronounced, he is not the worse that keeps it.
column13562: But neither doth the blessing nor curse in the law intend a supposition that men may be just by the law, but rather to show the perfection of the law, and that though a blessing be annexed thereto, no man by it can obtain that blessing; for not the hearers of the law are justified before God, but the doers, when they do it, shall be justified.

column13642: I shall, therefore, end this second reason with what I have said before--'Men must be justified from the curse in the sight of God while sinful in themselves.'
column13643: The Third Reason.--Another reason why not one under heaven can be justified by the law, or by his own personal performances to it, is, because since sin was in the world, God hath rejected the law and the works thereof for life (Rom 7:10).
column13644: It is true, before man had sinned, it was ordained to be unto life; but since, and because of sin, the God of love gave the word of grace.

column13646: Methinks, since it hath pleased God to reject the law and the righteousness thereof for life, such dust and ashes as we are should strive to consent to his holy will, especially when in the room of this [covenant] of works there is established a better covenant, and that upon better promises.

column13668: The heart of man is the seat of the law.

column13672: Conscience is Little-ease, if men resist it, whether it be rightly or wrongly informed.

column13678: Reasoning suiteth much with the law.

column13702: [27] Besides, he that shall think both to do and believe for justification before God from the curse, he seeks for life but as it were by the law, he seeks for life but as it were by Christ; and he being not direct in either, shall for certain be forsaken of either.

column13710: 'I am,' saith he, 'not able to look up'; not up to Christ for mercy.

column13712: The serpents that bit the people in the days of old were types of guilt and sin (Num 21:6).
column13713: Now, these were fiery serpents, and such as, I think, could fly (Isa 14:29).
column13714: Wherefore, in my judgment, they stung the people about their faces, and so swelled up their eyes, which made it the more difficult for them to look up to the brazen serpent, which was the type of Christ (John 3:14).
column13715: Just so doth sin by the law do now.
column13716: It stings the soul, the very face of the soul, which is the cause that looking up to Jesus, or believing in him, is so difficult a task in time of terror of conscience.
column13718: This is not only so at present, but so long as guilt is on the conscience, so long remains the blindness; for guilt standing before the soul, the grace of God is intercepted, even as the sun is hid from the sight of mine eyes by the cloud that cometh between.
column13719: 'My sin,' said David, 'is ever before me,' and so kept other things out of his sight; sin, I say, when applied by the law (Psa 51:3).
column13720: When the law came to Paul, he remained without sight until the good man came unto him with the word of forgiveness of sins (Acts 9).
column13722: Again; where the law comes with power, there it begetteth many doubts against the grace of God; for it is only a revealer of sin, and the ministration of death; that is, a doctrine that sheweth sin, and condemneth for the same; hence, therefore, as was hinted before, the law being the revealer of sin, where that is embraced, there sin must needs be discovered and condemned, and the soul for the sake of that.
column13723: Further, it is not only a revealer of sin, but that which makes it abound; so that the closer any man sticks to the law for life, the faster sin doth cleave to him.
column13724: 'That law,' saith Paul, 'which was ordained to be unto life, I found to be unto death,' for by the law I became a notorious sinner; I thought to have obtained life by obeying the law, 'but sin taking occasion by the commandment, deceived me, and by it slew me' (Rom 7:10-14).
column13725: A strange way of deceivableness, and it is hid from the most of men; but, as I have already told you, you see how it comes to pass.
column13727: Man by nature is carnal, and the law itself is spiritual: now betwixt these two ariseth great difference; the law is exceeding good, the heart exceeding bad; these two opposites, therefore, the heart so abiding, can by no means agree.
column13729: Therefore, at every approach of the law to the heart with intent to impose duty, or to condemn for the neglect thereof; at every such approach the heart starteth back, especially when the law comes home indeed, and is heard in his own language.
column13730: This being thus, the conscience perceiving this is a fault, begins to tremble at the sense of judgment; the law still continueth to command to duty, and to condemn for the neglect thereof.
column13731: From this struggling of these two opposites ariseth, I say, those doubts and fears that drive the heart into unbelief, and that make it blind to the word of the gospel, that it can neither see nor understand anything but that it is a sinner, and that the law must be fulfilled by it, if ever it be saved.
column13733: But again; another thing that hath great influence upon the heart to make it lean to the law for life is, the false names that Satan and his instruments have put upon it; such as these--to call the law the gospel; conscience, the Spirit of Christ; works, faith; and the like: with these, weak consciences have been mightily pestered; yea, thousands deluded and destroyed.
column13734: This was the way whereby the enemy attempted to overthrow the church of Christ of old; as, namely, those in Galatia and at Corinth, &c. (2 Cor 11:3,4,13,14).
column13735: I say, by the feigned notion that the law was the gospel, the Galatians were removed from the gospel of Christ; and Satan, by appropriating to himself and his ministers the names and titles of the ministers of the Lord Jesus, prevailed with many at Corinth to forsake Paul and his doctrine.
column13736: Where the Lord Jesus hath been preached in truth, and something of his doctrine known, it is not there so easy to turn people aside from the sound of the promise of grace, unless it be by the noise and sound of a gospel.
column13737: Therefore, I say, the false apostles came thus among the churches: 'another gospel, another gospel'; which, in truth, saith Paul, 'is not another; but some would pervert the gospel of Christ,' and thrust that out of doors, by gilding the law with that glorious name (Gal 1:6-8).
column13738: [29] So again, for the ministers of Satan, they must be called the apostles of Christ, and ministers of righteousness; which thing, I say, is of great force, especially being accompanied with so holy and just a doctrine as the word of the law is; for what better to the eye of reason than to love God above all, and our neighbour as ourselves, which doctrine, being the scope of the ten words given on Sinai, no man can contradict; for, in truth, they are holy and good.
column13739: But here is the poison; to set this law in the room of a mediator, as those do that seek to stand just before God thereby; and then nothing is so dishonourable to Christ, nor of so soul-destroying a nature as the law; for that, thus placed, hath not only power when souls are deluded, but power to delude, by its real holiness, the understanding, conscience, and reason of a man; and by giving the soul a semblance of heaven, to cause it to throw away Christ, grace, and faith.
column13740: Wherefore it behoveth all men to take heed of names, and of appearances of holiness and goodness.
column13742: Lastly, Satan will yet go further; he will make use of something that may be at a distance from a moral precept, and therewith bring souls under the law.
column13743: Thus he did with some of old; he did not make the Galatians fall from Christ by virtue of one of the ten words, but by something that was aloof off; by circumcision, days, and months, that were Levitical ceremonies; for he knows it is no matter, nor in what Testament he found it, if he can therewith hide Christ from the soul--'Behold, I Paul say unto you, that if ye be circumcised, Christ shall profit you nothing.
column13744: For I testify again to every man that is circumcised, that he is a debtor to do the whole law' (Gal 5:2,3).
column13745: Why so, seeing circumcision is not one of the ten words [commandments]?
column13746: Why, because they did it in conscience to God, to stand just before him thereby.
column13747: Now here we may behold much cunning of the devil; he begins with some at a distance from that law which curseth, and so by little and little bringeth them under it; even as by circumcision the Galatians were at length brought under the law that condemneth all men to the wrath and judgment of God.
column13748: I have often wondered when I have read how God crieth out against the Jews, for observing his own commandment (Isa 1:11-14).
column13749: But I perceive by Paul that by these things a man may reject and condemn the Lord Jesus; which those do, that for life set up aught, whether moral or other institution, besides the faith of Jesus.
column13750: Let men therefore warily distinguish betwixt names and things, betwixt statute and commandment, lest they by doing the one transgress against the other (2 Cor 1:19,20).
column13751: Study, therefore, the nature and end of the law with the nature and end of the gospel; and if thou canst keep them distinct in thy understanding and conscience, neither names nor things, neither statutes nor commandments, can draw thee from the faith of the gospel.
column13752: And that thou mayest yet be helped in this matter, I shall now come to speak to the second conclusion.
column13755: THAT MEN CAN BE JUSTIFIED FROM THE CURSE BEFORE GOD, WHILE SINNERS IN THEMSELVES, BY NO OTHER RIGHTEOUSNESS THAN THAT LONG AGO PERFORMED BY, AND REMAINING WITH, THE PERSON OF CHRIST.
column13756: For the better prosecuting of this position I shall observe two things--FIRST, That the righteousness by which we stand just before God, from the curse, was performed by the person of Christ.
column13757: SECOND, That this righteousness is inherent only in him.
column13759: As to the first of these, I shall be but brief.
column13760: Now, that the righteousness that justifieth us was performed long ago by the person of Christ, besides what hath already been said, is further manifest thus-- First.
column13761: He is said to have purged our sins by himself--'When he had by himself purged our sins, he sat down on the right hand of God' (Heb 1:3).
column13762: I have showed that in Christ, for the accomplishing of righteousness, there was both doing and suffering; doing, to fulfil all the commands of the law; suffering, to answer its penalty for sin.
column13763: This second is that which in this to the Hebrews is in special intended by the apostle, where he saith he hath purged our sins, that is, by his precious blood; for it is that alone can purge our sins, either out of the sight of God or out of the sight of the soul (Heb 9:14).
column13764: Now this was done by himself, saith the apostle; that is, in or by his personal doings and sufferings.
column13765: And hence it is that when God had rejected the offerings of the law, he said, 'Lo, I come.
column13766: A body hast thou prepared me,--to do thy will, O God' (Heb 10:5-8).
column13767: Now by this will of God, saith the Scripture, we are sanctified.
column13769: Why, by the offering up of the body of Jesus Christ; for that was God's will, that thereby we might be a habitation for him; as he saith again--'Jesus also, that he might sanctify the people with his own blood, suffered without the gate' (Heb 13:12).
column13771: As it is said, he hath purged our sins by himself, so it was by himself at once--'For by one offering he hath perfected for ever them that are sanctified' (10:14).
column13772: Now by this word 'at once,' or by 'one offering,' is cut off all those imaginary sufferings of Christ which foolish men conceive of; as that he in all ages hath suffered or suffereth for sin in us.
column13773: [30] No; he did this work but once.
column13774: 'Nor yet that he should offer himself often, as the high priest entereth into the holy place every year with blood of others; for then must he often have suffered since the foundation of the world: but now once in the end of the world,' in the time of Pilate, 'hath he appeared to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself' (Heb 9:25,26).
column13775: Mark how to the purpose the Holy Ghost expresseth it: he hath suffered but once; and that once, now; now once; now he is God and man in one person; now he hath taken the body that was prepared of God; now once in the end of the world hath he appeared to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself; by the offering up of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.
column13777: It further appears, in that by his resurrection from the dead the mercies of God are made sure to the soul, God declaring by that, as was said before, how well pleased he is by the undertaking of his Son for the salvation of the world: 'And as concerning that he raised him up from the dead, now no more to return to corruption, he said on this wise, I will give you the sure mercies of David' (Acts 13:34).
column13778: For Christ being clothed with man's flesh, and undertaking for man's sins, did then confirm all sure to us by his resurrection from the dead.
column13779: So that by the rising of that man again, mercy and grace are made sure to him that hath believed on Jesus.
column13780: Wherefore, from these things, together with what hath been discovered about his addressing himself to the work, I conclude 'that men can be justified from the curse, before God, while sinners in themselves, by no other righteousness than that long ago performed by the person of Christ.'
column13781: Now the conclusion is true from all show of contradiction; for the Holy Ghost saith he hath done it; hath done it by himself, and that by the will of God, at once, even then when he took the prepared body upon him--'By the will of God we are sanctified, through the offering up of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.'
column13783: This being so, the second position is also manifest--namely, that the righteousness by which we stand just from the curse, before God, is only inherent in Jesus Christ.
column13784: For if he hath undertaken to bring in a justifying righteousness, and that by works and merits of his own, then that righteousness must of necessity be inherent in him alone, and ours only by imputation; and hence it is called, in that fifth to the Romans, the gift, the 'gift of righteousness'; because neither wrought nor obtained by works of ours, but bestowed upon us, as a garment already prepared, by the mercy of God in Christ (Rom 5:17; Isa 61:10).
column13785: There are four things that confirm this for a truth-- First.
column13786: This righteousness is said to be the righteousness of one, not of many; I mean of one properly and personally, as his own particular personal righteousness.
column13787: The gift of grace, which is the gift of righteousness, it is 'by one man, Jesus Christ.'
column13788: 'Much more they which receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness shall reign in life by ONE, Jesus Christ.
column13789: Therefore as by the offence of one, judgment came upon all to condemnation; even so by the righteousness of ONE, the free gift came upon all men unto justification of life.
column13790: For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of ONE shall many be made righteous' (Rom 5:15-19).
column13791: Mark, the righteousness of one, the obedience of one; the righteousness of one man, of one man, Jesus.
column13792: [31] Wherefore, the righteousness that justifieth a sinner, it is personally and inherently the righteousness of that person only who, by works and acts of obedience, did complete it, even the obedience of one, of one man, Jesus Christ; and so ours only by imputation.
column13793: It is improper to say, Adam's eating of the forbidden fruit was personally and inherently an act of mine.
column13794: It was personally his, and imputatively mine; personally his, because he did it; imputatively mine, because I was then in him.
column13795: Indeed, the effects of his personal eating is found in my person; to wit, defilement and pravity.
column13796: The effects also of the imputation of Christ's personal righteousness are truly found in those that are in him by electing love and unfeigned faith, even holy and heavenly dispositions; but a personal act is one thing, and the effects of that another.
column13797: The act may be done by, and be only inherent in one; the imputation of the merit of the act, as also the effects of the same, may be in a manner universal, extending itself unto the most, or all.
column13798: This the case of Adam and Christ doth manifest.
column13799: The sin of one is imputed to his posterity; the righteousness of the other is reckoned the righteousness of those that are his.
column13801: The righteousness by which we stand just before God from the curse is called, 'The righteousness of the Lord--the righteousness of God--the righteousness of Jesus Christ,' &c. (Phil 3:6-9); and that by way of opposition to the righteousness of God's own holy law--'That I might be found in him, not having on my own righteousness, which is of the law, but that which is through the faith of Christ, the righteousness which is of God by faith.'
column13802: Now, by this opposition, as by what was said before, the truth is made exceeding clear; for by these words, 'not having my own righteousness,' are not only excluded what qualifications we suppose to be in us, but the righteousness through which we stand just in the sight of God by them is limited and confined to a person absolutely distinct.
column13803: Distinct, I say, as to his person and performances, who here is called God and Jesus Christ; as he saith also in the prophet Isaiah, 'In the Lord shall all the seed of Israel be justified, and shall glory' (Isa 45:25).
column13804: In the Lord, not in the law; in the Lord, not in themselves.
column13805: 'And their righteousness is of me, saith the Lord.'
column13806: Of me, not of themselves; of me, not of the law (54:17).
column13807: And again; 'Surely, shall one say, in the Lord have I righteousness and strength' (45:24).
column13808: Now, as I have already said, all this is to be understood of the righteousness that was fulfilled by acts and works of obedience, which the person of the Son of God accomplished in the days of his flesh in the world; by that man, I say, 'The Lord our righteousness' (Jer 23:5).
column13809: Christ, indeed, is naturally and essentially righteousness; but as he is simply such, so he justifieth no man; for then he need not to bear our sins in his flesh, and become obedient in all points of the law for us; but the righteousness by which we stand just before God is righteousness consisting of works and deeds, of the doings and sufferings, of such a person who also is essentially righteousness.
column13810: And hence, as before I have hinted, we are said to be justified by the obedience and blood of the Lord Jesus Christ, by the doings and sufferings of the Son of God.
column13811: And hence, again, it is that he first is called King of righteousness; that is, a King of righteousness as God-man, which of necessity supposeth his personal performances; and after that, 'King of peace' (Heb 7:1-3).
column13812: For what he is naturally and eternally in his Godhead, he is not to us, but himself; but what he is actively and by works, he is not to himself, but to us; so, then, he is neither King of righteousness nor of peace to us, as he is only the eternal Son of the Father, without his being considered as our priest and undertaker.
column13813: He hath 'obtained,' by works of righteousness, 'eternal redemption for us' (Heb 9:12).
column13814: So then, the righteousness by which we stand just before God is a righteousness inherent only in Christ, because a righteousness performed by him alone.
column13815: Now, that righteousness by which we stand just before God must be a righteousness consisting of personal performances; the reason is, because persons had sinned; this the nature of justice requireth, that 'since by man came death, by man' should come 'also the resurrection from the dead' (1 Cor 15:21).
column13816: The angels, therefore, for this very reason, abide under the chains of everlasting darkness, because he 'took not hold on them' (Heb 2:16,17); that is, by fulfilling righteousness for them in their nature.
column13817: That is a blessed word, to you.
column13818: 'To you is born this day in the city of David a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord.'
column13819: To YOU, not to angels; to you is born a Saviour (Luke 2:11).
column13821: It is yet further evident that the righteousness by which we stand just before God from the curse, is a righteousness inherent, not in us, but Christ; because it is a righteousness besides, and without the law itself.
column13822: Now take away the law, and you take away the rule of righteousness.
column13823: Again; take away the rule, and the act as to us must cease.
column13824: 'But now the righteousness of God without the law is manifested, being witnessed by the law and the prophets' (Rom 3:21).
column13825: So then, by such a righteousness we are justified as is not within the power of the law to command of us.
column13827: But what law is that which hath not power to command our obedience in the point of our justification with God?
column13829: The moral law, or that called the ten commandments.
column13830: Therefore we are neither commanded to love God, or our neighbour, as the means or part of our justifying righteousness; nay, he that shall attempt to do these things to be delivered from the curse thereby, by the scripture is holden accursed of God.
column13831: 'As many as are of the works,' or duties, 'of the law, are under the curse,' &c. (Gal 3:10).
column13832: Because we are justified not by that of the law, but by the righteousness of God without the law; that is, without its commanding of us, without our obedience to it--'Freely by his grace, through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus; whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation, through faith in his blood' (Rom 3:24,25).
column13833: This is the righteousness of God without the law; that is, without any of our obedience to the law.
column13834: Wherefore the righteousness by which we stand just, in the sight of God, cannot be inherent in us, but in Christ the King thereof.
column13836: This is further made apparent, by the capacity that God will consider that soul in, to whom he imputeth justifying righteousness; and that is, 'as one that worketh not,' as one that stands ungodly in the judgment of the law (Rom 4:4,5).
column13837: But this I have handled before, and therefore shall pass it here.
column13840: If any works of ours could justify us before God, they would be works after faith received; but it is evident that these do not; therefore the righteousness that justifies us from the curse before God is a righteousness inherent only in Christ.
column13841: That works after faith do not justify us from the curse, in the sight of God, is evident-- 1.
column13842: Because no works of the saints can be justified by the moral law, considering it as the law of works for life (Gal 3:10).
column13843: For this must stand a truth for ever--Whatsoever justifieth us must be justified by the moral law, for that is it that pronounceth the curse; unless, then, that curse be taken away by the work, the work cannot justify us before God (Rom 3:21).
column13844: But the curse cannot be taken away but by a righteousness that is first approved of by that law that so curseth; for if that shall yet complain for want of a full satisfaction, the penalty remaineth.
column13845: This is evident to reason, and confirmed by the authority of God's Word, as hath been already proved; because the law, once broken, pronounceth death, expecteth death, and executeth the same on him that will stand to the judgment of the law; but no work of a believer is capable of answering this demand of the law; therefore none of his works can justify him before God; for the law, that notwithstanding, complaineth.
column13847: No works of faith can justify us from the curse before God, because of the want of perfection that is in the greatest faith in us.
column13848: Now, if faith be not perfect, the work cannot be perfect; I mean with that perfection as to please Divine justice.
column13849: Consider the person, one that hath to do with God immediately by himself.
column13850: Now, that faith is not capable of this kind of perfection, it is evident, because when men here know most, they know but in part.
column13851: Now he that knows but in part, can do but in part; and he that doth but in part, hath a part wanting in the judgment of the justice of God.
column13852: So then, when thou hast done all thou canst, thou hast done but part of thy duty, and so art short of justification from the curse by what thou hast done (1 Cor 8:2, 13:12).
column13854: Besides, it looks too like a monster that the works of faith should justify us before God; because then faith is turned, as it were, with its neck behind it.
column13855: [32] Faith, in its own nature and natural course, respecteth the mercy of God through the Mediator, Jesus Christ; and as such, its virtue and excellency is to expect justification by grace through him; but by this doctrine faith is turned round about, and now makes a life out of what itself hath done; but, methinks, faith should be as noble as its fruits, that being the first, and they but the fruits of that.
column13856: Besides, seeing the work is only good because it floweth from faith (for faith purifieth the heart), therefore faith is it that justifies all its works (Acts 15:9).
column13857: If, then, we be justified by either, it is by faith, and not by his works; unless we will say there is more virtue in the less than in the greater.
column13858: Now, what is faith but a believing, a trusting, or relying act of the soul?
column13859: What, then, must it rely upon or trust in?
column13860: Not in itself; that is, without Scripture; not in its works, they are inferior to itself; besides, this is the way to make even the works of faith the mediator between God and the soul, and so by them thrust Christ out of doors; therefore it must trust in Christ; and if so, then no man can be justified from the curse, before God, by the works that flow from faith.
column13862: To put all out of doubt; the saint, when he hath done what he can to bring forth good works by faith, yet he dares not show these works before God but as they pass through the Mediator Christ, but as they are washed in the blood of the Lamb.
column13863: And therefore Peter saith, those sacrifices of ours that are truly spiritual are only then accepted of God, when offered up by Jesus Christ (1 Peter 2:5).
column13864: And therefore it is said again, that the prayers of the saints, which are the fruits of faith, come up before the throne of God through the angel's hand; that is, through the hand of Christ, through his golden censer, perfumed with his incense, made acceptable by his intercession (Rev 8:3,4).
column13865: It is said in the Book of Revelation, that it is granted to the bride, the Lamb's wife, that she should be 'arrayed in fine linen, clean and white; which white linen is the righteousness of saints.'
column13866: This fine linen, in my judgment, is the works of godly men, their works that sprang from faith.
column13869: Not simply because they were the works of faith.
column13870: But mark, they 'washed their robes, and made them white in the blood of the Lamb.'
column13871: And 'therefore they stand before the throne of God' (Rev 7:14,15).
column13872: Yea, therefore it is that their good works stand there too.
column13873: I conclude, then, 'our persons are justified while we are sinners in ourselves.'
column13874: Our works, even the works of faith, are no otherwise accepted but as they come through Jesus Christ, even through his intercession and blood.
column13875: So then, Christ doth justify both our person and works, not by way of approbation, as we stand in ourselves or works before God, but by presenting of us to his Father by himself, washing what we are and have from guilt in his blood, and clothing us with his own performances.
column13876: This is the cause of our acceptance with God, and that our works are not cast forth of his presence.
column13878: USE FIRST.--Is justifying righteousness to be found in the person of Christ only?
column13879: Then this should admonish us to take heed of seeking it in ourselves; that is, of working righteousness, thereby to appease the justice of God, lest by so doing we affront and blaspheme the righteousness of Christ.
column13880: He that shall go about to establish his own righteousness, he, as yet, doth defiance to that which is of God, of God's appointing, of God's providing; and that only wherewith the justice of the law must be well pleased.
column13881: Wherefore take heed, I say, of doing such a thing, lest it provoke the eyes of the Lord's glory--'When I shall say to the righteous, that he shall surely live; if he trust to his own righteousness, and commit iniquity, all his righteousnesses shall not be remembered; but for his iniquity that he hath committed, he shall die for it' (Eze 33:13).
column13882: Mark, though he be righteous, yea, though he have a promise of life, yet he shall die.
column13884: Because he sinned against the Lord by trusting to his own righteousness, therefore he must die for it.
column13885: There are some things that will preserve a man from splitting upon this rock.
column13887: Get good acquaintance with the covenant of grace, and of the persons concerned in the conditions of that covenant.
column13888: The conditions of that covenant are, that a righteousness shall be brought into the world that shall please the justice of God, and answer and so remove the curse of the law.
column13889: Now he that doth perform this condition is Christ; therefore the covenant is not immediately with man, but with him that will be the Mediator betwixt God and man: 'As for thee also, by the blood of thy covenant, I have sent forth thy prisoners,' speaking of Christ (Zech 9:11).
column13890: So then, Christ, the Man Christ, is he who was to bring in these conditions; to wit, everlasting righteousness.
column13891: And hence it is that God hath said, Christ shall be the covenant of the people--that is, he shall be our conditions to Godward (Dan 9:23,24).
column13892: He, therefore, is all our righteousness as to the point of our justification before God; he is the covenant of the people, as well as the light of the Gentiles; for as no man can see but in the light of his Spirit, so no man can stand but in and by him; he is the covenant of the people, the conditions and qualifications of the people (Isa 52:6).
column13893: So that to Godward Christ is all in all, and no man anything at all.
column13894: He hath made with me an everlasting covenant; with me, as I stand in my head, Christ, who, because he hath brought in everlasting righteousness, therefore hath removed the curse of the law; wherefore he adds, this covenant 'is ordered in all things, and sure,' because all points that concern me, as to redemption from the curse, are taken away by Christ, as before is discoursed (2 Sam 23:5).
column13895: Look, then, upon Christ as the man, the mediator, undertaker, and accomplisher of that righteousness in himself, wherein thou must stand just before God; and that he is the covenant or conditions of the people to Godward, always having in himself the righteousness that the law is well pleased with, and always presenting himself before God as our only righteousness.
column13897: That this truth may be the more heartily inquired into by thee, consider thine own perfections;[33] I say, study how polluted thou art, even from the heart throughout.
column13898: No man hath a high esteem of the Lord Jesus that is a stranger to his own sore.
column13899: Christ's church is an hospital of sick, wounded, and afflicted people; even as when he was in the world, the afflicted and distressed set the highest price upon Jesus Christ.
column13901: They were sick, and he was the Physician; but the whole had no need of him.
column13902: And just thus it is now: Christ is offered to the world to be the righteousness and life of sinners, but no man will regard him save he that seeth his own pollution; he that seeth he cannot answer the demands of the law, he that sees himself from top to toe polluted, and that therefore his service cannot be clean as to justify him from the curse before God--he is the man that must needs die in despair and be damned, or must trust in Jesus Christ for life.
column13903: Further, This rule I would have all receive that come to Jesus Christ for life and salvation-- 1.
column13904: Not to stick at the acknowledgment of sin, but to make that of it which the law makes of it: 'Acknowledge thine iniquity,' saith the Lord (Jer 3:13).
column13905: This is a hard pinch, I know what I say, for a man to fall down under the sense of sins by acknowledging them to be what the Lord saith they are; to acknowledge them, I say, in their own defiling and polluting nature; to acknowledge them in their unreasonable and aggravating circumstances; to acknowledge them in their God-offending and soul-destroying nature, especially when the conscience is burdened with the guilt of them.
column13906: Yet this is duty: 'If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive' (1 John 1:9).
column13907: Yea, to this is annexed the promise, 'He that confesseth and forsaketh them shall find mercy.'
column13908: This made David, as it were, lay claim to the mercy of God--'Wash me thoroughly,' said he, 'from mine iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin; for I acknowledge my transgression, and my sin is ever before me.'
column13909: Though, then, thou art to blush and be ashamed when thou rememberest thy sins and iniquities, yet do not hide them--'He that covereth his sins shall not prosper.'
