column17539: How should he be the Christ, and yet come out of Galilee, out of which ariseth no prophet?
column17541: Hence note, that though the prophecies and promises be full and plain as these were, that he should be born in Bethlehem, yet men's sins may cause them to be fulfilled in such obscurity, that instead of having benefit thereby, they may stumble and split their souls thereat.
column17542: Take heed then; hunt not Christ from plain promises with Herod, hunt him not from Bethlehem, lest he appear to your amazement and destruction from Egypt, or in the land of Zabulon!
column17543: But this much to the second question; to wit, What it was for Jesus to come into the world.
column17544: I come now to the third question.
column17545: [WHAT IT WAS FOR JESUS TO COME TO BE A SAVIOUR.]
column17548: What it was for him to come to be a Saviour.
column17549: For the further handling of this question I must show--First.
column17550: What it is to be a Saviour.
column17552: What it is to come to be a Saviour.
column17554: What it is for Jesus to come to be a Saviour.
column17556: What it is TO BE a Saviour.
column17558: A saviour supposeth some in misery, and himself one that is to deliver them.
column17560: A saviour is either such an one ministerially or meritoriously.
column17561: Ministerially is, when one person engageth or is engaged by virtue of respect or command from superiors, to go and obtain, by conquest or the king's redemption, the captives, or persons grieved by the tyranny of an enemy.
column17562: And thus were Moses and Joshua, and the judges and kings of Israel, saviours--'Thou deliveredst them into the hands of their enemies, who vexed them: and in the time of their trouble, when they cried unto thee, thou heardest them from heaven; and according to thy manifold mercies thou gavest them saviours, who saved them out of the hand of their enemies' (Neh 9:27).
column17563: Thus was Jesus Christ a Saviour; he was engaged by virtue of respect and command from God to obtain, by conquest and redemption, the captives or persons grieved.
column17564: God sent his Son to be 'the Saviour of the world' (John 4:42).
column17565: Meritoriously is, when the person engaging shall, at his own proper cost and charge, give a sufficient value or price for those he redeemeth.
column17566: Thus those under the law were redeemed by the money called the redemption-money--'And Moses gave the money of those that were redeemed unto Aaron and to his sons' (Num 3:46-51).
column17567: And thus was Jesus Christ a Saviour.
column17568: He paid full price to Divine justice for sinners, even his own precious blood--'Forasmuch as ye know that ye were not redeemed with corruptible things, as silver and gold, from your vain conversation, received by tradition from your fathers, but with the precious blood of Christ' (1 Peter 1:18,19).
column17569: And forasmuch as, in man's redemption, the undertaker must have respect, not only to the paying of a price, but also to the getting of a victory; for there is not only justice to satisfy, but death, devil, hell, and the grave, to conquer; therefore hath he also by himself gotten the victory over these.
column17572: He hath been the destruction of the grave (Hosea 13:14).
column17573: He hath gotten the keys of hell (Rev 1:18).
column17574: And this, I say, he did by himself, at his own proper cost and charge, when he triumphed over them upon his cross (Col 2:14,15).
column17576: What it is TO COME to be a Saviour.
column17578: To come to be one, supposeth one ordained and fore-prepared for that work--'Then said he, Lo, I come, a body hast thou prepared me' (Heb 10).
column17580: To come to be a Saviour supposeth one commissionated or authorized to that work--'The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he hath anointed me,' authorized me, 'to preach the gospel to the poor; he hath sent met to heal the broken-hearted, to preach deliverance to the captives, and recovering of sight to the blind, to set at liberty them that are bruised' (Luke 4:18).
column17581: And upon this account it is that he is so often called Christ, or the Anointed One; the anointed Jesus, or Jesus the Anointed Saviour.
column17582: 'Thou art the Christ, the Son of God, which should come into the world.'
column17583: 'This Jesus whom I preach unto you is Christ.'
column17584: He 'testified to the Jews that Jesus was Christ,' 'and confounded the Jews which dwelt at Damascus, proving' by the Scriptures 'that this is very Christ' (John 11:27; Acts 9:22, 17:3, 18:5); the very anointed of God, or he whom God authorized and qualified to be the Saviour of the world.
column17586: To come to be a Saviour supposeth a resolution to do that work before he goeth back--'I will ransom them from the power of the grave; I will redeem them from death: O death, I will be thy plagues; O grave, I will be thy destruction; repentance shall be hid from mine eyes' (Hosea 13:14).
column17587: And as he resolved, so he hath done.
column17589: By one offering he hath perfected for ever them that are sanctified (Heb 10:14).
column17590: He hath obtained eternal redemption for them (Heb 9:12; 2 Tim 1:10; Heb 9:26; Col 2:15; Heb 6:18-20).
column17592: I come now to the third question--What it is for JESUS to come to be a Saviour.
column17594: It is the greatest discovery of man's misery and inability to save himself therefrom that ever was made in the world.
column17595: Must the Son of God himself come down from heaven?
column17596: or can there be no salvation?
column17598: Cannot man by any means redeem his brother, nor give to God a ransom for him?
column17600: Cannot all the angels do it?
column17601: No; Christ must come and die to do it.
column17603: It is the greatest discovery of the love of God that ever the world had, for God so to love the world as to send his Son!
column17604: For God so to commend his love to the world as to send it to them in the blood of his Son!
column17608: It is the greatest discovery of the condescension of Christ that ever the world had, that he should not come 'to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many' (Matt 20:28).
column17609: That he should be manifest for this purpose, 'that he might destroy the works of the devil' (1 John 3:8).
column17610: That he should come that we 'might have life, and that we might have it more abundantly' (John 10:10).
column17611: That the Son of God should 'come to seek and to save that which was lost' (Luke 19:10).
column17612: That he should not come 'to judge the world, but to save the world' (John 12:47).
column17613: That 'Christ Jesus should come into the world to save sinners, of whom I am the chief' (1 Tim 1:15).
column17614: That he should 'love us, and wash us from our sins in his own blood' (Rev 1:5).
column17615: What amazing condescension and humility is this!
column17617: HOW JESUS CHRIST ADDRESSED HIMSELF TO THE WORK OF OUR REDEMPTION.
column17618: I come, then, in the next place, to show you how Jesus Christ addressed himself to the work of man's redemption.
column17619: The Scripture saith, 'he became poor,' that he made himself of no reputation, and took upon him the form of a servant, that he humbled himself unto death, even the death of the cross.
column17621: He took upon him our flesh.
column17623: He was made under the law.
column17625: He took upon him our sins.
column17627: He bore the curse due to our sins.
column17630: He took upon him our flesh.
column17631: I showed you before that he came in our flesh, and now I must show you the reason of it--namely, because that was the way to address himself to the work of our redemption.
column17632: Wherefore, when the apostle treated of the incarnation of Christ, he added withal the reason--to wit, that he might be capable to work out the redemption of men.
column17633: There are three things to be considered in this first head.
column17635: That he took our flesh for this reason--that he might be a Saviour.
column17637: How he took flesh, that he might be our Saviour.
column17639: That it was necessary that he should take our flesh, if indeed he will be our Saviour.
column17640: [He took our flesh, that he might be a Saviour.]
column17643: That he took our flesh for this reason--that he might be a Saviour: 'For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God, sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh' (Rom 8:3).
column17644: The sum of the words is, Forasmuch as the law could do us no good, by reason of the inability that is in our flesh to do it--for the law can do us no good until it be fulfilled--and because God had a desire that good should come to us, therefore did he send his Son in our likeness, clothed with flesh, to destroy, by his doing the law, the tendency of the sin that dwells in our flesh.
column17645: He therefore took our flesh, that our sin, with its effects, might by him be condemned and overcome.
column17646: The reason, therefore, why he took flesh is, because he would be our Saviour--'Forasmuch, then, as the children are partakers of flesh and blood, he also himself likewise took part of the same; that through death he might destroy him that had the power of death, that is, the devil; and deliver them who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage' (Heb 2:14,15).
column17647: In these words it is asserted that he took our flesh for certain reasons.
column17649: Because the children, the heirs of heaven, are partakers of flesh and blood--'Forasmuch, then, as the children are partakers of flesh and blood, he also himself took part of the same.'
column17650: Had the children, the heirs, been without flesh, he himself had not taken it upon him; had the children been angels, he had taken upon him the nature of angels; but because the children were partakers of flesh, therefore leaving angels, or refusing to take hold of angels, he took flesh and blood, the nature of the children, that he might put himself into a capacity to save and deliver the children; therefore it follows, that 'through death he might destroy him that had the power of death, that is, the devil.'
column17652: This, therefore, was another reason--that he might destroy the devil.
column17653: The devil had bent himself against the children; he is their adversary, and goeth forth to make war with them--'Your adversary, the devil.--And he went to make war with the remnant of her seed' (1 Peter 5:8; Rev 12:17).
column17654: Now the children could not destroy him, because he had already cast them into sin, defiled their nature, and laid them under the wrath of God.
column17655: Therefore Christ puts himself among the children, and into the nature of the children, that he might, by means of his dying in their flesh, destroy the devil--that is, take away sin, his [the devil's] work, that he might destroy the works of the devil; for sin is the great engine of hell, by which he overthroweth all that perish.
column17656: Now this did Christ destroy by taking on him the similitude of sinful flesh; of which more anon.
column17658: 'That he might destroy him that had the power of death, that is, the devil, and deliver them.'
column17659: This was the thing in chief intended, that he might deliver the children, that he might deliver them from death, the fruit of their sin, and from sin, the sting of that death--'That he might deliver them who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage.'
column17660: He took flesh, therefore, because the children had it; he took it that he might die for the children; he took it that he might deliver the children from the works of the devil--'that he might deliver them.'
column17661: No deliverance had come to the children if the Son of God had not taken their flesh and blood; therefore he took our flesh, that he might be our Saviour.
column17662: Again, in a Saviour there must be not only merit, but compassion and sympathy, because the children are yet to live by faith, are not yet come to the inheritance--'Wherefore it behoved him in all things to be made like unto his brethren, that he might be a merciful and faithful High-priest in things pertaining to God, to make reconciliation for the sins of the people' (Heb 2:17,18).
column17663: Two reasons are rendered in this text why he must take flesh--namely, that he might be their priest to offer sacrifice, to wit, his body and blood for them; and that he might be merciful and faithful, to pity and preserve them unto the kingdom appointed for them.
column17664: Mark you, therefore, how the apostle, when he asserteth that the Lord Jesus took our flesh, urgeth the reason why he took our flesh--that he might destroy the devil and death, that he might deliver them.
column17665: It behoveth him to be made like unto his brethren, that he might be merciful and faithful, that he might make reconciliation for the sins of the people.
column17666: The reason, therefore, why he took our flesh is declared--to wit, that he might be our Saviour.
column17667: And hence you find it so often recorded.
column17668: He hath 'abolished in his flesh the enmity.'
column17669: He hath 'slain the enmity' by his flesh.
column17670: 'And you that were sometimes alienated and enemies in your mind by wicked works, yet now hath he reconciled in the body of his flesh through death, to present you holy and unblameable--in his sight' (Eph 2:15,16; Col 1:21,22).
column17673: I come now to the second question--to wit, How he took our flesh.
column17674: This must be inquired into; for his taking flesh was not after the common way; never any took man's flesh upon him as he, since the foundation of the world.
column17676: He took not our flesh like Adam, who was formed out of the ground; 'who was made of the dust of the ground' (Gen 2:7, 3:19).
column17678: He took not our flesh as we do, by carnal generation.
column17679: Joseph knew not his wife, neither did Mary know any man, till she had brought forth her first-born son (Matt 1:25; Luke 1:34).
column17681: He took flesh, then, by the immediate working and overshadowing of the Holy Ghost.
column17682: And hence it is said expressly, 'She was found with child of the Holy Ghost.'
column17683: 'Now the birth of Jesus Christ was on this wise: When as his mother Mary was espoused to Joseph, before they came together, she was found with child of the Holy Ghost' (Matt 1:18).
column17684: And hence again, when Joseph doubted of her honesty, for he perceived she was with child, and knew he had not touched her, the angel of God himself comes down to resolve his doubt, and said, 'Joseph, thou son of David, fear not to take unto thee Mary thy wife, for that which is conceived in her is of the Holy Ghost' (Matt 1:20).
column17685: But again, though the Holy Ghost was that by which the child Jesus was formed in the womb, so as to be without carnal generation, yet was he not formed in her without, but by, her conception--'Behold, thou shalt conceive in they womb, and bring forth a son, and shalt call his name JESUS' (Luke 1:31).
column17686: Wherefore he took flesh not only in, but of, the Virgin.
column17687: Hence he is called her son, the seed of the woman; and hence it is also that he is called the seed of Abraham, the seed of David; their seed, according to the flesh (Gen 12, 13:15, 22; Luke 1:31, 2:7; Rom 1:3, 9:5; Gal 3:16, 4:4).
column17688: And this, the work he undertook, required, 1.
column17689: It required that he should take our flesh.
column17691: It required that he should take our flesh without sin, which could not be had he taken it by reason of a carnal generation; for so all children are conceived in, and polluted with, sin (Psa 51).
column17692: And the least pollution, either of flesh or spirit, had utterly disabled him for the work, which to do, he came down from heaven.
column17693: Therefore, 'such an High-priest became us, who is holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, and made higher than the heavens' (Heb 7:26).
column17694: This mystery of the incarnation of the Son of God was thus completed, I say, that he might be in all points like as we are, yet without sin; for sin in the flesh disableth and maketh incapable to do the commandment.
column17695: Therefore was he thus made, thus made of a woman; and this the angel assigneth as the reason of this his marvellous incarnation.
column17696: 'The Holy Ghost,' saith he, 'shall come upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee; therefore also that holy thing that shall be born of thee shall be called the Son of God' (Luke 1:35).
column17697: The overshadowing of the Holy Ghost and the power of the Highest--the Father and the Holy Ghost--brought this wonderful thing to pass, for Jesus is a wonderful one in his conception and birth.
column17698: This mystery is that next to the mystery of three persons in one God; it is a great mystery.
column17699: 'Great is the mystery of godliness: God was manifest in the flesh.'
column17700: The conclusion is, that Jesus Christ took our flesh that he might be our Saviour; and that he might be our Saviour indeed, he thus took our flesh.
column17701: That it was necessary that he should take our flesh if he will be our Saviour.
column17703: I come now to the third thing--namely, that it was necessary that he should take our flesh if he will be our Saviour.
column17705: And that, first, from the nature of the work; his work was to save, to save man, sinking man, man that was 'going down to the pit' (Job 33:24).
column17706: Now, he that will save him that is sinking must take hold on him.
column17707: And since he was not to save a man, but men, therefore it was necessary that he should take hold, not of one person, but of the common nature, clothing himself with part of the same.
column17708: He took not hold of angels, 'but he took on him the seed of Abraham' (Heb 2:16).
column17709: For that flesh was the same with the whole lump of the children to whom the promise was made, and comprehended in it the body of them that shall be saved, even as in Adam was comprehended the whole world at first (Rom 5).
column17710: Hence we are said to be chosen in him, to be gathered, being in him, to be dead by him, to be risen with him, and to be set with him, or in him, in heavenly places already (Rom 7:4; Eph 1:4,10; Col 2:12,13, 3:1-3).
column17711: This, then, was the wisdom of the great God, that the Eternal Son of his love should take hold of, and so secure the sinking souls of perishing sinners by assuming their flesh.
column17713: The manner of his doing the work of a Saviour did call for his taking of our flesh.
column17714: He must do the work by dying.
column17716: Christ must needs have suffered,' or else no glory follows (Luke 24:26; Acts 17:3).
column17717: 'The prophets testified beforehand the sufferings of Christ, and the glory that should follow' (1 Peter 1:11).
column17718: Yea, they did it by the Spirit, even by the Spirit of Christ himself.
column17719: This Spirit, then, did bid them tell the world, yea, testify, that Christ must suffer, or no man be blest with glory; for the threatening of death and the curse of the law lay in the way between heaven gates and the souls of the children, for their sins; wherefore he that will save them must answer Divine justice, or God must lie, in saving them without inflicting the punishment threatened.
column17720: Christ, then, must needs have suffered; the manner of the work laid a necessity upon him to take our flesh upon him; he must die, he must die for us, he must die for our sins.
column17721: And this was effectually foretold by all the bloody sacrifices that were offered under the law--the blood of bulls, the blood of lambs, the blood of rams, the blood of calves, and the blood of goats and birds.
column17722: These bloody sacrifices, what did they signify, what were they figures of, but of the bloody sacrifice of the body of Jesus Christ?
column17723: their blood being a shadow of his blood, and their flesh being a shadow of his flesh.
column17724: Therefore, when God declared that he took no pleasure in them, because they could not make the worshippers perfect as pertaining to the conscience, then comes Jesus Christ to offer his sinless body and soul for the sin of the people--'For it is not possible that the blood of bulls and of goats should take away sin.
column17725: Wherefore, when he cometh into the world, he saith, Sacrifices and offering thou wouldest not, but a body hast thou prepared me; in burnt-offerings and sacrifices for sin thou hast had no pleasure.
column17726: Then said I, Lo, I come, in the volume of the book it is written of me, to do thy will, O God.'
column17727: Since burnt-offerings cannot do thy will, my body shall; since the blood of bulls and goats cannot do thy will, my blood shall.
column17728: Then follows, By the will of God 'we are sanctified, through the offering up of the body of Jesus Christ once for all' (Heb 10:4-10).
column17730: The end of the work required that Christ, if he will be our Saviour, should take upon him our flesh.
column17731: The end of our salvation is, that we might enjoy God, and that he by us might be glorified for ever and ever.
column17734: 'I will dwell in them, and they shall be my people, and I will be their God.'
column17735: This indwelling of God, and consequently our enjoyment of him, begins first in its eminency by his possessing our flesh in the person of Jesus Christ.
column17736: Hence his name is called 'Immanuel, God with us'; and 'the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us.'
column17737: The flesh of Christ is the tabernacle which the Lord pitched, according to that saying, 'The tabernacle of God is with men, and he will dwell with them, and they shall be his people, and God himself shall be with them, and be their God' (Rev 21:3).
column17738: Here God beginneth to discover his glory, and to be desirable to the sons of men.
column17739: God could not communicate himself to us, nor take us into the enjoyment of himself, but with respect to that flesh which his Son took of the Virgin, because sin stood betwixt.
column17740: Now this flesh only was the holy lump, in this flesh God could dwell; and forasmuch as this flesh is the same with ours, and was taken up with intent that what was done in and by that, should be communicated to all the children; therefore through that doth God communicate of himself unto his people--'God was in Christ, reconciling the world unto himself' (2 Cor 5:19).
column17741: And 'I am the way,' saith Christ, 'no man cometh unto the Father but by me' (John 14:6).
column17742: That passage to the Hebrews is greatly to our purpose.
column17743: We have boldness, brethren, 'to enter into the holiest,' the place where God is, 'by the blood of Jesus, by a new and living way, which he hath consecrated for us, through the veil, that is to say, his flesh' (Heb 10:19,20).
column17744: Wherefore by the flesh and blood of Christ we enter into the holiest; through the veil, saith he, that is to say, his flesh.
column17746: As the end of our salvation is that we might enjoy God, so also it is that he by us might be glorified for ever--'That God in all things might be glorified, through Jesus Christ our Lord.'
column17747: Here indeed will the mystery of his grace, wisdom, justice, power, holiness, and glory, inhabit eternal praise, while we that are counted worthy of the kingdom of God shall admire at the mystery, and see ourselves, without ourselves, even by the flesh and blood of Christ through faith therein, effectually and eternally saved.
column17748: Oh, this will be the burden of our eternal joy--God loved us, and gave his Son for us; Christ loved us, and gave his flesh for our life, and his blood for our eternal redemption and salvation!
column17749: THAT CHRIST WAS MADE UNDER THE LAW.
column17751: But, secondly CHRIST WAS MADE UNDER THE LAW--'When the fulness of the time was come, God sent forth his Son, made of a woman, made under the law' (Gal 4:4).
column17752: Of right, being found in flesh, he must needs be under the law, for that there is not any creature above or without law to God; but this is not to the point in hand.
column17753: Christ was not therefore under the law because he was found in flesh, but he took flesh, and designedly put himself, or was made under the law; wherefore it is added, He was made under the law to 'redeem,' to redeem them that were under that law.
column17754: Wherefore, here is a design, a heavenly contrivance and device on foot; Christ is made--that is, by design subjected--under the law, for the sake and upon the account of others, 'to redeem them that were under the law.'
column17755: Made under the law--that is, put himself into the room of sinners, into the condition of sinners; made himself subject to the same pains and penalties we were obnoxious to.
column17756: We were under the law, and it had dominion over us, bound us upon pain of eternal damnation to do completely all things written in the law.
column17757: This condition Christ put himself into that 'he might redeem'; for assuredly we had else perished.
column17758: The law had dominion over us, and since we had sinned, of right it pronounced the curse, and made all men subject to the wrath of God.
column17759: Christ, therefore, did not only come into our flesh, but also into our condition, into the valley and shadow of death where we were, and where we are, as we are sinners.
column17760: He that is under the law is under the edge of the axe.
column17761: When David was to go to visit his brethren, and to save them from the hand of Goliath, he was to look how his brethren fared, and to 'take their pledge' (1 Sam 17:18).
column17762: This is true of Jesus Christ when he came to save us from the hand of death and the law; he looked how his brethren fared, took to heart their deplorable condition, and put himself into the same plight--to wit, under the law, that he might redeem them that were under the law.
column17763: I told you before that he came sinless into the world, that he had a miraculous conception, and wonderful birth; and here you see a reason for it, he was to be put, or made, under the law, 'to redeem.'
column17764: He that will be made under the law to redeem, had need be sinless and spotless himself; for the law findeth fault with the least, and condemneth man for the first beginning of, sin.
column17765: Without this, then, there could not have been redemption, nor any the sons of God by adoption: no redemption, because the sentence of death had already passed upon all; no sons by adoption, because that is the effect of redemption.
column17766: 'God sent forth his Son, made of a woman, made under the law, to redeem them that were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons.'
column17767: Christ, then, by being made under the law, hath recovered his from under the law, and obtained for them the privilege of the adoption of sons.
column17768: For, as I told you before, Christ stood a common[3] person, presenting in himself the whole lump of the promised seed, or the children of the promise; wherefore he comes under the law for them, takes upon him to do what the law required of them, takes upon him to do it for them.
column17769: He began, therefore, at the first tittle of the law, and going in man's flesh, for man, through the law, he becomes 'the end of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth.'
column17770: The END of the law--what is the end of the law but perfect and sinless obedience?
column17771: that is the end of the law, both with respect to its nature, and the cause of its being imposed.
column17772: God gave the law, that complete righteousness should by that be found upon men; but because sin was got into man's flesh, therefore this righteousness, by us, could not be completed.
column17773: Now comes Christ the Lord into the world, clothes himself with the children's flesh, addresseth himself to the work of their redemption, is made under the law; and going through every part of the law without sin, he becometh 'the end of the law for' justifying 'righteousness to every one that believeth' (Rom 10:4).
column17774: For he obeyed not the law for himself, he needed no obedience thereto; it was we that needed obedience, it was we that wanted to answer the law; we wanted it but could not obtain it, because then the law was weak through the flesh; therefore God sent his own Son, and he did our duty for us, even to become the end of the law to every one that believeth.
column17775: In this, therefore, Christ laboured for us, he was made under the law to redeem.
column17776: Therefore, as I said before, it behoved him to be sinless, because the law binds over to answer for sin at the bar of the judgment of God.
column17777: Therefore did his Godhead assume our human flesh, in a clean and spotless way, that he might come under 'the law, to redeem them that were under the law.'
column17778: For, consisting of two natures, and the personality lying in the Godhead, which gave value and worth to all things done for us by the manhood, the obedience takes denomination from thence, to be the obedience of God.
column17779: The Son's righteousness, the Son's blood; the righteousness of God, the blood of God (Heb 5:8,9; Phil 3:9; Acts 20:28; 1 John 3:16).
column17780: Thus Jesus Christ came into the world under the law to redeem, not simply as God, but God-man, both natures making one Christ.
column17781: The Godhead, therefore, did influence and give value to the human flesh of Christ in all its obedience to the law, else there would have been wanting that perfection of righteousness which only could answer the demands and expectation of the justice of God; to wit, perfect righteousness by flesh.
column17782: But the second Person in the Godhead, the Son, the Word, coming under the law for men in their flesh, and subjecting himself by that flesh to every tittle and demand of the law; all and every whit of what was acted and done by Jesus Christ, God-man, for us, it was and is the righteousness of God; and since it was not done for himself, but for us, as he saith in the text, 'to redeem,' the righteousness by which we are set free from the law is none other but the righteousness that alone resideth in the person of the Son of God.
column17783: And that it is absolutely necessary thus it should be, is evident, both with respect to God and also with respect to man.
column17785: The righteousness is demanded by God; therefore he that comes to redeem must present before God a righteousness absolutely perfect; this can be done by none but God.
column17787: Man was to present this righteousness to God; therefore must the undertaker be man.
column17788: Man for man, and God for God, God-man between God and man.
column17789: This daysman can lay his hand upon us both, and bring God and man together in peace (Job 9:33).
column17791: But some may say, what need of the righteousness of one that is naturally God?
column17792: Had Adam, who was but a mere man, stood in his innocency, and done his duty, he had saved himself and all his posterity.
column17794: Had Adam stood, he had so long secured himself from the wages of sin, and posterity so long as they were in him.
column17795: But had Adam sinned, yea, although he had not defiled his nature with filth, he could never after that have redeemed himself from the curse of the law, because he was not equal with God; for the curse of the law is the curse of God; but no man can deliver himself from the curse of God, having first transgressed.
column17796: This is evident, because angels, for sin, lie bound in chains, and can never deliver themselves.
column17797: He, therefore, that redeemeth man from under the law must not only do all the good that the law requireth, but bear all the penalty that is due by the law for sin.
column17798: Should an angel assume human flesh, and in that flesh do the law, this righteousness would not redeem a sinner; it would be but the righteousness of an angel, and so, far short of such a righteousness as can secure a sinner from the wrath of God.
column17799: But 'thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy soul, with all thy heart, with all thy mind, with all thy strength.'
column17800: If there were no more required of us now to redeem ourselves, it would be utterly impossible for us to do it, because in the best there is sin, which will intermix itself with every duty of man.
column17801: This being so, all the heart, all the soul, all the strength, and all the mind, to the exact requirement of the justice of the law, can never be found in a natural man.
column17802: Besides, for this work there is required a perfect memory, always to keep in mind the whole duty of man, the whole of every tittle of all the law, lest sin come in by forgetfulness; a perfect knowledge and judgment, lest sin come in by ignorance; an everlasting unweariedness in all, lest sin and continual temptation tire the soul, and cause it to fail before the whole be done.
column17803: For the accomplishing of this last, he must have--1.
column17804: A perfect willingness, without the least thought to the contrary.
column17806: Such a hatred of sin as is not to be found but in the heart of God.
column17808: A full delight in every duty, and that in the midst of all temptations.
column17810: A continuing in all things to the well-pleasing of the justice of God.
column17811: I say, should the penalty of the law be taken off, should God forgive the penalty and punishment due to sins that are past, and only demand good works now, according to the tenor of the law, no man could be saved; there would not be found that heart, that soul, that mind, and that strength, anywhere in the world.
column17812: This, therefore, must cease for ever, unless the Son of God will put his shoulder to the work; but, blessed be God, he hath done it--'When the fulness of the time was come, God sent forth his Son, made of a woman, made under the law, to redeem them that were under the law.'
column17813: CHRIST TOOK UPON HIM OUR SINS.
column17815: But thirdly, CHRIST OUR SAVIOUR TAKES UPON HIM OUR SINS.
column17816: This is another step to the work of our redemption.
column17817: 'He hath made him to be sin for us.'
column17819: A fool would think it blasphemy; but Truth hath said it.
column17820: Truth, I say, hath said, not that he was made to sin, but that God made him to be sin--'He hath made him to be sin for us' (2 Cor 5:21).
column17821: This, therefore, showeth us how effectually Christ Jesus undertook the work of our redemption--He was made to be sin for us.
column17822: Sin is the great block and bar to our happiness; sin is the procurer of all miseries to men both here and for ever.
column17823: Take away sin, and nothing can hurt us; for death temporal, death spiritual, and death eternal, are the wages of sin (Rom 6:23).
column17824: Sin, then, and man for sin, is the object of the wrath of God.
column17825: If the object of the wrath of God, then is his case most dreadful; for who can bear, who can grapple with the wrath of God?
column17826: Men cannot, angels cannot, the whole world cannot.
column17827: All, therefore, must sink under sin, but he who is made to be sin for us; he only can bear sins, he only can bear them away, and therefore were they laid upon him--'The Lord hath laid upon him the iniquity of us all' (Isa 53:6).
column17828: Mark, therefore, and you shall find that the reason why God made him to be sin for us was, 'that we might be made the righteousness of God in him.'
column17829: He took our flesh, he was made under the law, and was made to be sin for us, that the devil might be destroyed, that the captives might be redeemed, and made the righteousness of God in him.
column17830: And forasmuch as he saith that God 'hath made him to be sin,' it declareth that the design of God and the mystery of his will and grace was in it.
column17831: 'He hath made him to be sin.'
column17832: God hath done it, that we might be made the righteousness of God in him.
column17833: There was no other way; the wisdom of heaven could find no other way; we could not by other means stand just before the justice of God.
column17834: Now, what remains but that we who are reconciled to God by faith in his blood are quit, discharged, and set free from the law of sin and death?
column17835: Yea, what encouragement to trust in him, when we read that God 'made him to be sin for us.'
column17837: But how was Jesus Christ made of God to be sin for us?
column17839: Even so as if himself had committed all our sins; that is, they were as really charged upon him as if himself had been the actor and committer of them all.
column17840: 'He hath made him to be sin,' not only as a sinner, but as sin itself.
column17841: He was as the sin of the world that day he stood before God in our stead.
column17842: Some, indeed, will not have Jesus Christ our Lord to be made sin for us; their wicked reasons think this to be wrong judgment in the Lord; it seems, supposing that because they cannot imagine how it should be, therefore God, if he does it, must do it at his peril, and must be charged with doing wrong judgment, and so things that become not his heavenly Majesty; but against this duncish sophistry[4] we set Paul and Isaiah, the one telling us still, 'the Lord hath laid on him the iniquity of us all'; and the other, that 'God made him to be sin for us.'
column17843: But these men, as I suppose, think it enough for Christ to die under that notion only, not knowing nor feeling the burden of sin, and the wrath of God due thereto.
column17844: These make him as senseless in his dying, and as much without reason, as a silly sheep or goat, who also died for sin, but so as in name, in show, in shadow only.
column17845: They felt not the proper weight, guilt, and judgment of God for sin.
column17846: But thou, sinner, who art so in thine own eyes, and who feelest guilt in thine own conscience, know thou that Jesus Christ, the Son of the living God in flesh, was made to be sin for thee, or stood sensibly guilty of all thy sins before God, and bare them in his own body upon the cross.
column17847: God charged our sins upon Christ, and that in their guilt and burden, what remaineth but that the charge was real or feigned?
column17848: If real, then he hath either perished under them, or carried them away from before God; if they were charged but feignedly, then did he but feignedly die for them, then shall we have but feigned benefit by his death, and but a feigned salvation at last--not to say how this cursed doctrine chargeth God and Christ with hypocrisy, the one in saying, He made Christ to be sin; the other in saying that he bare our sin; when, in deed and in truth, our guilt and burden never was really upon him.
column17850: But might not Christ die for our sins but he needs must bear their guilt or burden?
column17852: He that can sever sin and guilt, sin and the burden, each from other, laying sin and no guilt, sin and no burden on the person that dieth for sin, must do it only in his own imaginative head.
column17853: No scripture, nor reason, nor sense, understandeth or feeleth sin when charged without its guilt and burden.
column17854: And here we must distinguish between sin charged and sin forgiven.
column17855: Sin forgiven may be seen without guilt or burden, though I think not without shame in this world; but sin charged, and that by the justice of God--for so it was upon Christ--this cannot be but guilt and the burden, as inseparable companions, must unavoidably lie on that person.
column17856: Poor sinner, be advised to take heed of such deluded preachers who, with their tongues smoother than oil, would rob thee of that excellent doctrine, 'God hath made him to be sin for us'; for such, as I said, do not only present thee with a feigned deliverance and forgiveness, with a feigned heaven and happiness, but charge God and the Lord Jesus as mere impostors, who, while they tell us that Christ was made of God to be sin for us, affirm that it was not so really, suggesting this sophistical reason, 'No wrong judgment comes from the Lord.'
column17857: I say again, this wicked doctrine is the next way to turn the gospel in thy thoughts to no more than a cunningly-devised fable (2 Peter 1:16), and to make Jesus Christ, in his dying for our sins, as brutish as the paschal lamb in Moses' law.
column17858: Wherefore, distressed sinner, when thou findest it recorded in the Word of truth that Christ died for our sins, and that God hath made him to be sin for us, then do thou consider of sin as it is a transgression against the law of God, and that as such it procureth the judgment of God, torments and afflicts the mind with guilt, and bindeth over the soul to answer it.
column17859: Sever not sin and guilt asunder, lest thou be an hypocrite like these wicked men, and rob Christ of his true sufferings.
column17860: Besides, to see sin upon Christ, but not its guilt; to see sin upon Christ, but not the legal punishment, what is this but to conclude that either there is no guilt and punishment in sin, or that Christ bare our sin, but we the punishment?
column17861: for the punishment must be borne, because the sentence is gone out from the mouth of God against sin.
column17862: Do thou therefore, as I have said, consider of sin as a transgression of the law (1 John 3:4), and a provoker of the justice of God; which done, turn thine eye to the cross, and behold those sins, in the guilt and punishment of them, sticking in the flesh of Christ.
column17863: 'God condemned sin in the flesh' of Christ (Rom 8:3).
column17864: He 'bare our sins in his own body on the tree' (1 Peter 2:24).
column17865: I would only give thee this caution--Not sin in the nature of sin--sin was not so in the flesh of Christ; but sin in the natural punishment of it--to wit, guilt, and the chastising hand of justice.
column17866: 'He was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities; the chastisement of our peace was upon him, and with his stripes we are healed' (Isa 53:5).
column17867: Look, then, upon Christ crucified to be as the sin of the world, as if he only had broken the law; which done, behold him perfectly innocent in himself, and so conclude that for the transgression of God's people he was stricken; that when the Lord made him to be sin, he made him to be sin for us.
column17868: [5] HE WAS MADE A CURSE FOR US.
column17870: As he was made flesh under the law, and also sin, SO HE WAS MADE A CURSE FOR US--'Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us; as it is written, Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree.'
column17871: This sentence is taken out of Moses, being passed there upon them that for sin are worthy of death--'And if a man have committed a sin worthy of death, and thou hang him on a tree, his body shall not remain all night upon the tree, but thou shalt in anywise bury him that day, for he that is hanged is accursed of God' (Deut 21:22,23).
column17872: By this sentence Paul concludeth that Jesus Christ was justly hanged, because sin worthy of death was upon him; sin, not of his own, but ours.
column17873: Since, then, he took our sins, he must be cursed of God; for sin is sin wherever it lies, and justice is justice wherever it finds it; wherefore since Jesus Christ will bear our sin, he must be 'numbered with the transgressors,' and counted worthy to die the death.
column17874: He that committeth sin is worthy of death.
column17875: This, though Christ did not personally do, his members, his body, which is his church did; and since he would undertake for them with God, and stand in their sins before the eyes of his justice, he must die the death by the law.
column17876: Sin and the curse cannot be severed.
column17877: Sin must be followed with the curse of God.
column17878: Sin therefore being removed from us to the back of Christ, thither goes also the curse; for if sin be found upon him, he is the person worthy to die--worthy by our sins.
column17879: Wherefore Paul here setteth forth Christ clothed with our sins, and so taking from us the guilt and punishment.
column17880: What punishment, but the wrath and displeasure of God?--'Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us.'
column17881: In this word 'curse' are two things comprised, 1.
column17882: The reality of sin; for there can be no curse where there is no sin, either of the person's own, or made to be his by his own consent or the imputation of Divine justice.
column17883: And since sins are made to be Christ's by imputation, they are his, though not naturally, yet really, and consequently the wages due.
column17884: He hath made him to be sin; he was made a curse for us.
column17886: This word 'curse' compriseth, therefore, the punishment of sin, that punishment properly due to sin from the hand of God's justice, which punishment standeth in three things--(1.)
column17887: In charging sin upon the body and soul of the person concerned; and hence we read that both the body and soul of Christ 'were made an offering for sin' (Isa 53:10; Heb 10:10).
column17889: The punishment standeth in God's inflicting of the just merits of sin upon him that standeth charged therewith, and that is death in its own nature and strength; to wit, death with the sting thereof--'The sting of death is sin.'
column17890: This death did Christ die because he died for our sins.
column17892: The sorrows and pains of this death, therefore, must be undergone by Jesus Christ.
column17893: Now there are divers sorrows in death--such sorrows as brutes are subject to; such sorrows as persons are subject to that stand in sin before God; such sorrows as those undergo who are swallowed up of the curse and wrath of God for ever.
column17894: Now so much of all kinds of sorrow as the imputation of our sin could justly bring from the hand of Divine justice, so much of it he had.
column17896: He had the sting of death, which is sin.
column17897: He was forsaken of God; but could not by any means have those sorrows which they have that are everlastingly swallowed up of them.
column17898: 'It was not possible that he should be holden of it' (Acts 2:24).
column17899: For where sin is charged and borne, there must of necessity follow the wrath and curse of God.
column17900: Now where the wrath and curse of God is, there must of necessity follow the effects, the natural effects--I say, the natural effects--to wit, the sense, the sorrowful sense of the displeasure of an infinite Majesty, and his chastisements for the sin that hath provoked him.
column17901: There are effects natural, and effects accidental; those accidental are such as flow from our weakness, whilst we wrestle with the judgment of God--to wit, hellish fear, despair, rage, blasphemy, and the like; these were not incident to Jesus Christ, he being in his own person every way perfect.
column17902: Neither did he always endure the natural effects; his merits relieved and delivered him.
column17903: God loosed the pains of death, 'because it was not possible that he should be holden of it.'
column17904: Christ then was made a curse for us, for he did bear our sin; the punishment therefore from the revenging hand of God must needs fall upon him.
column17905: Wherefore by these four things we see how Christ became our Saviour--he took hold of our nature, was born under the law, was made to be sin, and the accursed of God for us.
column17906: And observe it--all this, as I said before, was the handiwork of God.
column17907: God made him flesh, made him under the law, God made him to be sin, and also a curse for us.
column17908: The Lord bruised him, the Lord put him to grief, the Lord made his soul an offering for sin (Isa 53:10).
column17909: Not for that he hated him, considering him in his own harmless, innocent, and blessed person, for he was daily his delight; but by an act of grace to us-ward, were our iniquities laid upon him, and he in our stead was bruised and chastised for them.
column17910: God loved us, and made him a curse for us.
column17911: He was made a curse for us, 'that the blessing of Abraham might come on the Gentiles through [faith in] Jesus Christ' (Gal 3:14).
column17913: Before I pass this truth, I will present thee, courteous reader, with two or three demonstrations for its further confirmation.
column17915: That Christ did bear our sins and curse is clear, because he died, and that without a mediator.
column17916: He died--'The wages of sin is death' (Rom 6:23).
column17917: Now if death be the wages of sin, and that be true that Christ did die and not sin, either the course of justice is perverted, or else he died for our sins; there was 'no cause of death in him,' yet he died (Acts 13:28).
column17918: He did no evil, guile was not found in his mouth, yet he received the wages of sin (1 Peter 2:22).
column17919: Sin, therefore, though not of his own, was found upon him, and laid to his charge, because 'he died.'
column17920: 'Christ died for our sins,' Christ 'gave himself for our sins' (1 Cor 15:1-3; Gal 1:4).
column17921: He, then, that will conclude that Christ did not bear our sin, chargeth God foolishly, for delivering him up to death; for laying on him the wages, when in no sense he deserved the same.
column17922: Yea, he overthroweth the whole gospel, for that hangeth on this hinge--'Christ died for our sins.'
column17924: But all that die do not bear the curse of God for sin.
column17926: But all that die without a mediator do.
column17927: Angels died the cursed death because Christ took not hold of them; and they for whom Christ never prayeth, they die the cursed death, for they perish everlastingly in the unutterable torments of hell.
column17928: Christ, too, died that death which is the proper wages of sin, for he had none to stand for him.
column17929: 'I looked,' saith he, 'and there was none to help; and I wondered that there was none to uphold: therefore mine own arm brought salvation unto me.--And he saw that there was no man, and wondered that there was no intercessor; therefore his arm brought salvation unto him, and his righteousness it sustained him' (Isa 63:5, 54:16).
column17930: Christ then died, or endured the wages of sin, and that without an intercessor, without one between God and him; he grappled immediately with the eternal justice of God, who inflicted on him death, the wages of sin; there was no man to hold off the hand of God; justice had his full blow at him, and made him a curse for sin.
column17931: He died for sin without a mediator, he died the cursed death.
column17933: A second thing that demonstrateth that Christ died the cursed death for sin; it is, the frame of spirit that he was in at the time that he was to be taken.
column17934: Never was poor mortal so beset with the apprehensions of approaching death, as was this Lord Jesus Christ; amazement beyond measure, sorrow that exceeded, seized upon his soul.
column17935: 'My soul,' saith he, 'is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death.'
column17936: 'And he began,' saith Mark, 'to be sore amazed, and to be very heavy' (Matt 26:38; Mark 14:33).
column17937: Add to this, that Jesus Christ was better able to grapple with death, even better able to do it alone, than the whole world joined all together.
column17939: He was anointed with the Spirit without measure (John 3:34).
column17941: He had all grace perfect in him (John 1:16).
column17943: Never none so soaked in the bosom of his Father's love as himself (Prov 8:23-30).
column17945: Never none so harmless and without sin as he was, and, consequently, never man had so good a conscience as he had (Heb 7:26).
column17947: Never none prepared such a stock of good works to bear him company at the hour of death as he.
column17949: Never none had greater assurance of being with the Father eternally in the heavens than he.
column17950: And yet, behold, when he comes to die, how weak is he, how amazed at death, how heavy, how exceeding sorrowful!
column17951: and, I say, no cause assigned but the approach of death.
column17953: how often is it seen that we poor sinners can laugh at destruction when it cometh; yea, and 'rejoice exceedingly when we find the grave,' looking upon death as a part of our portion; yea, as that which will be a means of our present relief and help (Job 3:22; 1 Cor 3:22).
column17954: This Jesus Christ could not do, considered as dying for our sin, but the nearer death, the more heavy and oppressed with the thoughts of the revenging hand of God.
column17955: Wherefore he falls into an agony, and sweats; not after the common rate as we do when death is severing body and soul--'His sweat was as it were great drops [clodders] of blood falling down to the ground' (Luke 22:44).
column17956: What, I say, should be the reason, but that death assaulted him with his sting?
column17957: If Jesus Christ had been to die for his virtues only, doubtless he would have borne it lightly, and so he did as he died, bearing witness to the truth, 'He endured the cross, despising the shame' (Heb 12:2).
column17958: How have the martyrs despised death, and, as it were, not been careful of that, having peace with God by Jesus Christ, scorning the most cruel torments that hell and men could devise and invent!
column17959: but Jesus Christ could not do so, as he was a sacrifice for sin; he died for sin, he was made a curse for us.
column17960: O my brethren, Christ died many deaths at once, he made his grave with the wicked, and with the rich in his death.
column17961: Look how many thousands shall be saved--so many deaths did Jesus die; yet it was but once he died.
column17962: He died thy death, and my death, and so many deaths as all our sins deserved who shall be saved from the wrath to come.
column17963: Now, to feign that these sorrows and this bloody agony, was not real, but in show only, what greater condemnation can be passed upon Jesus Christ, who loved to do all things in the most unfeigned simplicity?
column17964: It was, therefore, because of sin, the sin that was put into the death he died, and the curse of God that was due to sin, that made death so bitter to Jesus Christ--'It is Christ that died.'
column17965: The apostle speaks as if never any died but Christ, nor indeed did there, so wonderful a death as he (Rom 8:34).
column17966: Death, considered simply as it is a deprivation of natural life, could not have these effects in a person, personally more righteous than an angel.
column17967: Yea, even carnal, wicked men, not awakened in their conscience, how securely can they die!
column17968: It must therefore also be concluded that the sorrows and agony of Jesus Christ came from a higher cause, even from the guilt of sin, and from the curse of God that was now approaching for that sin.
column17969: It cannot be attributed to the fear of men; their terror could not make him afraid; that was contrary to his doctrine, and did not become the dignity of his person; it was sin, sin, sin, and the curse due to sin.
column17971: It is evident that Christ did bear and die the cursed death for sin, from the carriage and dispensations of God towards him.
column17974: God now becomes as an enemy to him.
column17976: He forsakes him--'My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?'
column17977: Yea, the sense of the loss of God's comfortable presence abode with him even till he gave up the ghost.
column17979: He dealeth with him as with one that hath sinned, he chastiseth him, he bruiseth him, he striketh and smiteth him, and was pleased--that is, his justice was satisfied--in so doing.
column17980: 'It pleased the Lord to bruise him; he hath put him to grief' (Isa 53:10).
column17981: These things could not be, had he only considered him in his own personal standing.
column17983: Without the consideration of sin, he doth not willingly afflict nor grieve the children of men--that is, not out of pleasure, or without sufficient cause.
column17984: Jesus Christ, then, since he is under this withdrawing, chastising, bruising, and afflicting displeasure of God, he is all that time under sin, under our sins, and therefore thus accursed of God, his God.
column17986: Not only the carriage of God, but his dispensations, his visible dispensations, plainly declare that he stood before God in our sins.
column17987: Vengeance suffered him not to live.
column17988: Wherefore God delivered him up--'He spared not his own Son, but delivered him up for us all' (Rom 8:32).
column17990: He delivered him into the hands of men (Mark 9:31).
column17992: He was delivered into the hands of sinners (Luke 24:7).
column17996: Yea, so delivered up as that they both had him to put him to death, and God left him for that purpose in their hands; yea, was so far off from delivering him, that he gave way to all things that had a tendency to take his life from the earth.
column17997: Now many men do what they will with him, he was delivered to their will--Judas may sell him; Peter may deny him; all his disciples forsake him; the enemy apprehends him, binds him, they have him away like a thief to Caiaphas the high-priest, in whose house he is mocked, spit upon, his beard is twitched from his cheeks; now they buffet him and scornfully bow the knee before him; yea, 'his visage was so marred more than any man, and his form more than the sons of men' (Isa 52:14).
column17998: Now he is sent to the governor, defaced with blows and blood; who delivereth him into the hand of his soldiers; they whip him, crown him with thorns, and stick the points of the thorns fast in his temples by a blow with a staff in their hand; now he is made a spectacle to the people, and then sent away to Herod, who, with his men of war, set him at nought, no God appearing for his help.
column17999: In fine, they at last condemn him to death, even to the death of the cross, where they hang him up by wounds made through his hands and his feet, between the earth and the heavens, where he hanged for the space of six hours--to wit, from nine in the morning till three in the afternoon.
column18000: No God yet appears for his help; while he hangs there some rail at him, others wag their heads, others tauntingly say, 'He saved others, himself he cannot save'; some divide his raiment, casting lots for his garments before his face; others mockingly bid him come down from the cross, and when he desireth succour, they give him vinegar to drink.
column18001: No God yet appears for his help.
column18002: Now the earth quakes, the rocks are rent, the sun becomes black, and Jesus still cries out that he was forsaken of God; and presently boweth his head and dies (Matt 26, 27; Mark 14, 15; Luke 22, 23; John 18, 19).
column18003: And for all this there is no cause assigned from God but sin--'He was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities; the chastisement of our peace was upon him, and with his stripes we are healed' (Isa 53:5).
column18004: The sum then is, that Jesus Christ the Lord, by taking part of our flesh, became a public person, not doing or dying in a private capacity, but in the room and stead of sinners, whose sin deserved death and the curse of God; all which Jesus Christ bare in his own body upon the tree.
column18005: I conclude, then, that my sin is already crucified and accursed in the death and curse Christ underwent.
column18007: I come now to some objections.
column18009: Christ never was a sinner, God never supposed him to be a sinner, neither did our sins become really his; God never reputed him so to have been; therefore hate or punish him as a sinner he could not; for no false judgment can belong to the Lord.
column18011: That Christ was not a sinner personally, by acts or doings of his own, is granted; and in this sense it is true that God did never suppose him to be a sinner, nor punished him as such a sinner, nor did he really, if by really you understand naturally, become our sin, nor did God ever repute him so.
column18013: But that Christ stood before God in our sins, and that God did not only suppose him so to stand, but set him in them, put them upon him, and counted them as his own, is so true that he cannot at present be a Christian that denies it--'The Lord hath laid upon him the iniquities of us all' (Isa 53:6; 1 Peter 2:22).
column18015: So, then, though God did not punish him for sin of his own committing, yet he punished him for sin of our committing--'The just suffered for the unjust' (1 Peter 3:18).
column18017: Therefore it is true, that though Christ did never really become sin of his own, he did really become our sin, did really become our curse for sin.
column18018: If this be denied, it follows that he became our sin but feignedly, that he was made our curse, or a curse for us but in appearance, show, or in dissimulation; but no such action or work can proceed of the Lord.
column18019: He did then really lay our sin and his curse upon him for our sin.
column18021: But if Christ indeed hath suffered for our sins, and endured for them that curse that of justice is due thereto, then hath he also endured for us the proper torments of hell, for they are the wages of our sins.
column18023: Many things might be said in answer to this objection; but briefly--First.
column18024: What God chargeth upon the soul for sin is one thing, and what followeth upon that charge is another.
column18026: A difference in the person suffering may make a difference in the consequences that follow upon the charge.
column18027: Let us then consider of both these things.
column18029: The charge is sin--God charge him with our sins.
column18030: The person then stands guilty before the judgment of God.
column18032: The person charged sustains or suffereth the wrath of God.
column18034: This wrath of God is expressed and inflicted on body and soul.
column18035: The consequences are--God forsaketh the person charged, and being left, if he cannot stand, he falleth under the power of guilt and horror of the same.
column18036: If the person utterly fall under this charge, as not being able to wrestle with and overcome this wrath of God, then despair, horror of hell, rage, blasphemy, darkness, and damnable anguish, immediately swallow him up, and he lieth for ever and ever in the pains of hell, a monument of eternal vengeance.

column18222: SEVERAL DEMONSTRATIONS MORE, PROVING THE FORMER DOCTRINE.
column18223: But before I conclude this answer, I will give you nine or ten more undeniable demonstrations to satisfy you, if God will bless them to you, in the truth of this great doctrine--to wit, that Jesus Christ, by what he hath done, hath paid the full price to God for the souls of sinners, and obtained eternal redemption for them.
column18226: And, first, I begin with his resurrection.

column18228: Now, considering that at his death he was charged with our sins, and accursed to death for our sins, that justice that delivered him up for them must have amends made to him before he acquits him from them; for there can be no change in justice.
column18229: Had he found him in our sins in the grave, as he found him in them upon the tree (for he had them in his body on the tree), he had left him there as he had left him upon the tree; yea, he had as surely rotted in the grave, as ever he died on the tree (1 Peter 2:24).
column18230: But when he visited Christ in the grave, he found him a holy, harmless, undefiled, and spotless Christ, and therefore he raised him up from the dead--'He raised him up from the dead, having loosed the pains of death; because it was not possible that he should be holden of it' (Acts 2:24).

column18242: That is, by the merit of his undertaking he brought into the world, and set before the face of God, such a righteousness that outweigheth and goeth far beyond that sin, and so did hide sin from the sight of God; hence, he that is justified is said to have his sins hid and covered--'Blessed is he whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered' (Psa 32:1).
column18243: Covered with the righteousness of Christ--'I spread my skirt over thee, and covered thy nakedness,' thy sins (Eze 16:8).
column18244: Christ Jesus, therefore, having by the infiniteness of his merit taken away, put away, or hidden our sins from the face of God, therefore he raised him up from the dead.
